TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the bill is to strengthen the curfew at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. Honourable members will recognise the importance of balancing the interests of noise affected communities against the operational requirements of the airport.

PARA.TAB: The night hours are the most sensitive hours for noise around the airport. Communities affected by aircraft noise during the day deserve to be free of this disturbance during the night. The government is therefore committed to minimising, to the greatest extent possible, the activities at the airport during the night-time curfew period.

The government has already made significant improvements to the curfew regime over the past year. Last December, the government introduced a monetary penalty of up to $25,000 for curfew breaches. This replaced the previous arrangements where curfew breaches were dealt with administratively rather than by the courts and without provision for monetary penalties.

Last April the government introduced stricter limitations on movements by larger freight jets. Approvals for the operation of Boeing 737 and Airbus A300 freight aircraft have either lapsed or been withdrawn. Moreover, operations by McDonnell Douglas DC9 aircraft are being phased out and must be eliminated by May 1996. Permitted jet movements will then be restricted to the quieter British Aerospace Bae146 aircraft.

A strict approach has also been adopted in considering requests for dispensations from the curfew at Sydney airport. In the first six months of 1995, an average of 3 dispensations a month have been granted, compared with an average of approximately 25 curfew dispensations per month during 1994.

Regulations have been made to ensure that all night-time jet freight operations into Sydney airport are banned after the opening of Sydney West airport. The people of western Sydney can be reassured that the government's comprehensive updating of the environmental impact statement for the new airport will have as its central objective the prevention of noise nuisance arising from night-time operations. It is fundamentally important that we learn the lessons of Sydney airport and ensure that future generations of western suburbs residents are not exposed to excessive noise.

The private member's bill introduced by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in the last sittings, by proposing only to replicate the current curfew regulations in legislation, did nothing to ease the burden of the airport's operations at night on the residents of Sydney. After so strongly supporting the parallel runway development at Sydney airport, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) now seeks to deceive voters into thinking he will do something about the curfew. In reality he would do nothing.

At the request of the member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), the Howard private member's bill was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure with a view to strengthening the current curfew arrangements. Residents affected by aircraft noise in Sydney are fortunate to have an elected representative such as Mary Easson who recognised the need to strengthen the curfew and at whose instigation the committee was tasked to look at this issue. The measures in this bill are the direct result of her efforts on behalf of residents living around Sydney airport

I am grateful to Peter Morris and his committee for carrying out this inquiry and reporting in such a tight time frame. The proposals put forward by the committee comprise a significant package and have been of considerable assistance in the preparation of the bill now before the House.

This bill, in building on the current stricter curfew arrangements, goes much further to provide a range of new initiatives to strengthen and enhance the current controls. For this reason the government has decided to draft a new bill, rather than propose numerous amendments to the bill introduced by the Leader of the Opposition. The government's bill is aimed at minimising curfew aircraft operations at Sydney airport.

I would now like to respond to the committee's proposals.In their first two proposals the committee suggested steps to reduce the number of international passenger aircraft movements during the first and last hours of the curfew. The government accepts the absolute desirability of reducing the number of these movements.

Consistent with the committee's recommendations, the international entitlements in the bill reflect current usage patterns. This means an immediate reduction in the current international passenger jet entitlements between the hours of 5 a.m. and 6 a.m. from 42 movements per week, with no more than eight on any day, to a maximum of 35 movements per week, with no more than seven on any day. The bill also enables regulations to prescribe lower levels of entitlements. In line with the committee's proposal for a progressive phase-out, I envisage reducing entitlements whenever practicable.

Additionally, the bill introduces a regime requiring each individual international passenger movement during the curfew shoulder periods to be fully justified. International passenger movements during the shoulder periods will not be permitted once Sydney West airport is capable of handling those movements. In the interim, international passenger movements will only be approved if they can be justified by reason of curfew constraints at overseas airports or lack of available capacity at Sydney airport outside the curfew.

The bill establishes a process where operators of international passenger aircraft may apply to the Secretary of the Department of Transport for approval for specific flights. This will require the department and the industry to, for the first time, assess carefully the feasibility of rescheduling these shoulder hour flights into non-curfew times. This process is consistent with the committee's proposals.

Members of the public have complained about aircraft departing to the north of the airport just on 11 p.m. and therefore not clearing the suburbs until some time after the start of the curfew. In order to address this issue the bill contains a provision which requires all aircraft to depart over the bay after 10.45 p.m. If wind conditions preclude these take-offs the aircraft will not be permitted to depart.

The current arrangements allow an aircraft that has received a clearance to push back from a gate before 11 p.m. to depart during the curfew provided it takes off over Botany Bay. Certain operators have taken advantage of this provision and have been seeking, and receiving, push back clearances well before they are actually ready to depart. This has allowed some aircraft to depart from the airport well after 11 p.m. without breaching the regulations. In line with the committee's proposal this push back provision has been abolished. The bill before the House contains a provision based on taxi clearance, which means that aircraft will have to be actually available for take-off before 11 p.m.

As I stated earlier curfew movements by the larger jet freight aircraft have been, or are being, phased out. In order to ensure that the gains from this initiative are not circumvented by the use of larger and relatively noisy propeller-driven aircraft, the bill contains a provision which prohibits the use of propeller-driven aircraft which have a maximum take-off weight greater than 34,000 kilograms. This seeks to address the concerns expressed by the committee.

There has been considerable public disquiet about the issuing of curfew dispensations and the committee made a number of proposals in this area. In future, guidelines will be used in assessing applications for curfew dispensations. The preparation of these guidelines will be subject to a public consultation process. It is envisaged that, subject to this process, the guidelines will restrict any such operations to fly only over Botany Bay. However, there will be provision for dispensations to be granted for operations on other runways in the event of a force majeur situation arising; for instance, a civil emergency. There would be an exemption in those very special circumstances.

When a dispensation is granted, the bill requires the minister to table a statement outlining the reasons for the dispensation in each house of the parliament within five sitting days. The Morris committee suggested that the minister be given authority to increase the number of flights during the curfew for one-off events such as the 2000 Olympics. The government intends to ensure that Sydney airport and Sydney West airport, which will then be open, are capable of handling the level of air traffic during the Olympic period without the need to relax the curfew at Sydney airport. This proposal is therefore not accepted by the government.

Under the present curfew regulations the maximum fine for a breach of the curfew is $25,000 for a corporation. This is consistent with the Commonwealth criminal law policy that penalties in regulations are intended for minor offences only. By placing the curfew controls in this act, the penalties can be increased to be consistent with those imposed for similar offences under other legislation. The government therefore supports the committee's proposal that the bill provide for penalties of up to $20,000 for individuals and $100,000 for corporations.

The government is committed to improving the processes for community consultation on curfew issues. This is already demonstrated through the establishment of the Sydney airport community consultative committee chaired by the Hon. Joe Riordan. The Morris committee has proposed that this be further pursued through a general purpose standing committee of the House of Representatives.

The bill incorporates the consultation procedures currently before the parliament in the Legislative Instruments Bill. They will allow public scrutiny of any proposals to amend this bill once enacted. They will also apply to the development of instruments under this legislation. Adoption of these consultation procedures will not of course preclude any curfew issues being dealt with by a committee of the House when considered necessary.

The issue of residents being woken up early on weekend mornings by a succession of landings from the north starting at 6 a.m. has been a particular problem. The committee proposed that the feasibility of restricting operations over Botany Bay between the hours of 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. and 7 a.m. at weekends be examined. The bill adopts this proposal to give much needed relief in this area, whenever safe operations can be conducted over Botany Bay.

On occasions aircraft approach the airport from the south at night but `miss the approach' and have to abort their landings. Although this is an internationally accepted procedure and is essential to safe flying, it results in the aircraft flying over the suburbs to the north and creating significant noise disturbance. In order to explain to the community the reason for these events the committee proposed that operators place an explanatory advertisement in local newspapers within seven days of such an event.

This proposal has not been taken up in full due to advice of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority which considers that a statutory requirement for airlines themselves to give a public account for carrying out a missed approach may have an adverse effect on flight safety. However, consistent with the longstanding requirement for the reporting of the use of reverse thrust, the bill contains a requirement for an explanatory report to be provided to the Secretary to the Department of Transport when a missed approach occurs. This information will be made public through the Sydney airport community consultative committee.

The Morris committee noted that noise disturbance at night is not restricted to aircraft operating out of Sydney airport and that a study should be undertaken of the impacts of propeller-driven aircraft carrying out night-time operations around Sydney. The government accepts this. The proposed study will be carried out immediately.

As a first step to offset the noise impacts of propeller-driven aircraft operating into and out of Sydney airport at night, I propose to amend the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Flight Corridors) Regulations so that propeller-driven aircraft will be required to adhere to flight corridors over the Kurnell sandhills when landing or taking off during the curfew.
One final matter raised by the committee was that the noise complaint handling procedures at Sydney airport be reviewed. I am now taking steps to ensure that this is done.

With his ineffectual private member's bill having been gazumped by our curfew bill, I am aware that the Leader of the Opposition has foreshadowed a new stunt in the form of an amendment to `reopen' the east-west runway. Leaving aside the outrageous cynicism and cowardly deception displayed by the Leader of the Opposition in attempting to back away from his strident advocacy of the third runway, nothing could be more detrimental to the interests of those in the flight paths.

All our technical advice has been in favour of parallel runway operations, just as it would be if the Leader of Opposition were in office. If he ignored such advice from all the relevant agencies and outside experts, he would be directly and singularly responsible for running the airport in a manner that was less safe and a long way short of capacity.

In reality his notion of reopening the east-west runway is the airlines' proposal to use the eastern end of the runway for stub operations by propeller aircraft. Sure, this would overcome some of the safety and capacity problems—there is no doubt about that—but it would also free up the north-south axis for more jet movements, because it would eliminate those 10 propeller movements on the north-south axis at the moment. Indeed, the movement rate to the north would not be 80 to 85 overall movements per hour; it would be 80 to 85 jet movements per hour down that corridor, an increase of at least 10 jets per hour to the north—10 more jumbos thundering down that corridor.

The airlines would certainly be delighted because they could go on deferring any need to use Badgerys Creek and, therefore, any need to duplicate facilities. But the already suffering residents on the north-south flight path would face a huge increase in their noise burden, all thanks to the Leader of the Opposition.

Perhaps this is the reason he supported the third runway in 1989. Back then he was absolutely derisory about the issue of aircraft noise. Today, just as he tries to deceive people into believing he cares about the low paid, he is trying to say that he cares about noise affected residents. Well, the government will not let him get away with it. At every turn we will remind the electorate of everything he has previously said, and at the same time we will continue our own drive to provide genuine protection for the noise affected residents under the flight paths.

The government considers that the new measures introduced by the bill will significantly enhance the current curfew arrangements and will therefore bring much needed relief to residents living around Sydney airport. I commend the bill to the House.

Some of the air flights are in the minister's backyard, but the Leader of the Opposition would prefer all of them to be there. He would have all of them on the east-west runway if he could. Having been transformed into a nimby in regard to an airport, he thinks the minister should share them.

In today's debate on the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill this government, in a very positive role, is introducing legislation that will enshrine into a Commonwealth act arrangements for the management of Sydney airport during the curfew. It is all very well for the Leader of the Opposition to say that he brought this forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, he did.

—Of course, but what was it going to achieve? The shadow minister for transport interrupts, `He did.' Of course he did. We all know that. What was his motive? It was to score some cheap political points, to be seen to be trying to do something for the people when for years he was determined to impose more noise upon them. If those terrible electoral commissioners had not pushed those boundaries around, he would not have been affected.
—Tell us about the lies that were supposed to be law.

—Calm down, little fellow, because it does not affect south-west Queensland. It is a little bit distant from Mascot. What was the purpose of the bill that was brought in by the Leader of the Opposition after his newfound interest in aircraft noise? It was simply to enshrine into an act what already existed in regulation. Those regulations were drawn under the power provided in the Air Navigation Act. One could say that it really was a stunt, and thinking people know that it was a stunt. It was a stunt so he could be seen to be doing something for the people upon whom he had sought to inflict noise and disturbance for many years.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition does not have any credentials on this issue. He said that after 12 1/2 years the minister has just discovered there is a problem with the curfew. Living near the airport, the minister has known that fact for a bit longer than 12 1/2 years. He is well experienced in aircraft noise. He well understands the impact. Really, the Leader of the Opposition has taken 21 years to discover what he accuses the minister of having taken 12 1/2 years to discover—that is, aircraft noise is a problem.

When the Leader of the Opposition was helping to lead the charge for the third runway, he well knew what the impact would be, and we listened to his rather cursory remarks about the reopening of the east-west runway. The east-west runway can be and is used in conditions when the crosswinds are such that it is unsafe to use the north-south runways. The Leader of the Opposition made reference to several airports abroad that do use cross-runways in association with parallel runways. Amongst others, he referred to the airports of Los Angeles, Heathrow and Chicago's O'Hare.

But let us just put the facts on the table—not the cursory comments made by the Leader of the Opposition in what was really a furphy about the use of the east-west runway. Los Angeles airport has four parallel runways; it does not have intersecting runway operations. Heathrow, which is the busiest airport in the world in terms of international aircraft movements, has two parallel runways and a crosswind runway; but, as a general rule, the crosswind runway is not used unless the crosswind exceeds 20 knots. Over the period of 1984 to 1990, usage of the crosswind runway at Heathrow, as quoted by the Leader of the Opposition, averaged 1.4 per cent of total aircraft movements.

Is the Leader of the Opposition indicating for the use of the east-west runway at Mascot a 1.4 per cent use? Of course he is not. He wants to go back to the bad old days when he did not care about aircraft noise because it did not come anywhere near to Bennelong and his constituents. But the situation at Heathrow is somewhat similar to the situation at Sydney airport in that operations are generally confined to the parallel runway system which offers the greatest capacity, and the crosswind runway is only used when the crosswinds in the parallel system exceed a prescribed limit.

There are a number of heavily trafficked airports in the United States and Europe that have intersecting runway operations, including Chicago's O'Hare. But in a number of cases intersecting runway operations are necessary to cater for the large number of aircraft movements at these airports. Sydney is battling at around 225,000 movements per annum. Chicago's O'Hare airport had 841,000 aircraft movements in 1992. This compares to aircraft movements currently at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport of 225,000—and it can go up to 253,000. Is there a message in this? Is the Leader of the Opposition really saying that you can maximise further still the use of the Sydney Mascot system by bringing in the parallel runways and maximising the use of a crosswind runway so that the use of Mascot might be considerably even greater still, running along the lines of what is happening at Chicago?

There have been several incidents at various US airports, including Chicago's O'Hare airport, related to simultaneous operations on intersecting runways—and even at Kingsford Smith, at Mascot. The Bureau of Air Safety has advised that there were a total of 11 incidents relating to simultaneous operations over the five years up to the end of 1994 when parallel runways became the preferred mode of operation.

To put it in perspective, what the Leader of the Opposition has sought to do has been to present a false picture about the use of a crosswind runway, about the use of the east-west runway, at Mascot. He has tried somehow to muddy this altogether and say, `Well, if it's good enough to be done at Chicago's O'Hare airport or elsewhere in the United States, it ought to be good enough to be done in Australia.' I do not give any credence to the case mounted by the Leader of the Opposition. I have known him too long, I have heard him too often and I have been the butt too often of their criticism for being opposed to a third runway at Sydney airport. But they ran with it; they persuaded enough people on the third runway to ultimately lead to its being built. Now, having led the charge in that, they have to accept some responsibility for it.

On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, we appreciate the very positive response that has been given by the government to our report. Yes, it was done in a very tight timetable and, to achieve that tight timetable, we had to have the cooperation and support of the members of the committee, but particularly the members of the subcommittee: the deputy chairman of the committee, the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), who is in the chamber; the member for North Sydney (Mr Mack); the member for Lyons (Mr Adams); and the member for Lilley (Mr Swan). In particular, I would thank the staff: Mr Malcolm Aldons, the secretary, and Mrs June Murphy, who does all the hard work in connection with the publication of reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a long time since Laurie ever did some hard work.

—He is not on the committee. I express my appreciation to the rest of the committee who supported the report. I am sure that, like me, they are very pleased with the strong response the government has given to the report.

PARA.TAB: I will deal quickly with the parts of the report that address the issues involved. Airports are nimbys—everybody wants one but in somebody else's backyard. Everybody wants to utilise the services that an airport provides but they do not want to be affected by the noise and the disturbances that come from airports. The committee dealt with the issue of shoulder periods—that is, the period from 5 a.m. to 6 a.m. when up to 42 international flights a week are permitted to come in and between 11 p.m. and midnight when 14 flights a week are permitted to go out.

I want to press upon the House that those arrangements resulted from a policy understanding that there was not to be a third runway; they were a trade-off. At the time there was no third runway at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, and taking into account the fact that the arrival and departure of international aircraft are of such importance to the economy and to the overall scheduling arrangements and international curfews, it was thought that those arrangements would help ease the situation considerably.

Now that the third runway has been built and is in operation, the same case does not exist. Now that Badgerys Creek is on schedule and planned to come into operation in 1999 there will be further opportunity for international aircraft, as the markets grows and as traffic grows, to utilise that alternative destination. The airlines do not have a case to argue, as they did back in 1987-88, that there be a shoulder period.

What we proposed, and the government agreed to, was that the number of inbound slots currently being used—that is, 35 out of the 42 available—be frozen and that as airlines move out of those slots those slots be surrendered. As we get closer to 1999, the number of international flights arriving in the shoulder periods will further reduce.

The committee believes also, on the basis of evidence provided to us, that there is a capacity to move existing flights out of the shoulder periods, particularly in the morning, and into the ordinary periods—that is, post 6 a.m. We have that capacity for at least six months of the year. Depending on what the government does about Badgerys Creek in the future, it may even be possible to move to Badgerys Creek earlier. That has to also be borne in mind.

We were convinced that people suffer effects from aircraft noise. They have to be given adequate consideration in the arrangements for the management of airports. In the opinion of the members of the committee, at least a seven-hour period of freedom from aircraft noise is required. They should be free from noise from at least 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. from Monday to Friday. We also made a recommendation to look at extending it further on the weekends. The government is looking at that recommendation.

The other issue that came up was aircraft getting push-back clearances. This means that aircraft are continuing to load ostensibly before 11 p.m. but not departing until 11 p.m. or just after 11 p.m. and then transiting northern Sydney for a considerable time after 11 p.m. causing great disruption. When we pressed that issue we found that it involved one particular cargo operator operating a Boeing 727 to New Zealand.

The recommendation that a new clause be inserted to prohibit take-offs to the north after 10.45 p.m. is based on taxiway clearances. Once taxiway clearance is given, then no aircraft may take off other than to the south after 10.45 p.m. We felt that that would give considerable relief to people affected by aircraft noise.

It also became obvious to us that a number of propeller-driven aircraft wander around in uncontrolled airspace of Sydney at night at above 500 feet and below 2,000 feet. If the Leader of the Opposition wants to go out to Bankstown at 1 a.m. and hop on his private propeller-driven aircraft and go for a cruise over the Harbour Bridge, there is nothing stopping him. In the stillness of the night, when the ambient noise is at a very low level, the people of the northern areas of Sydney can be as disturbed by a low flying propeller-driven aircraft as others can be disturbed by much larger jet aircraft during the day.

There needs to be an investigation into those aircraft. It is quite clear that those aircraft can be managed. It is assumed by many people that those aircraft are originating and terminating at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. It was clear to us that they are not. Some propeller-driven aircraft are going from Sydney Kingsford Smith during the night, usually en route to Bankstown, or from Bankstown en route to Sydney Kingsford Smith. But there are other aircraft wandering about, either coming into Bankstown from the north or from the north-east or moving around in Sydney airspace that is uncontrolled.

The issue of penalties was raised with the committee. There is a recommendation, which has been accepted by the government, for an increase in the personal penalty up to a maximum of $20,000 and for corporations from $20,000 to $100,000. That gives a very clear indication to people that we need to let the airlines and the operators see that the government of the day is absolutely fair dinkum about this issue.

Another matter that was of constant concern to people coming before us was the noise hotline service. It was evident that that has not been operating in a way that provides satisfaction and information to people. People constantly complain that when you ring the hotline service you get an answering machine; you leave a message to be called back and no-one ever calls back. They ring to complain about an aircraft that is overhead, only to be told that the aircraft is not overhead—`There are no aircraft in the air because it is not showing on the chart.'

The matter that needs to be looked at is that those aircraft registering on the charts are those carrying transponders, and the propeller driven aircraft moving around that do not have transponders are not showing up on the noise charts. That is another matter that needs to be looked at. I understand from the minister that that service is being looked at to be strengthened and greatly improved so that those people, when they are disturbed, do have a contact to make, can have their voice heard and can have information provided on what has been taking place.

We were surprised—given the run-up to the government's decision in 1989 to construct a third runway and the enormous clamour that came from the opposition, from the airline industry and from the tourism organisations—that there was this deafening silence from all of those parties in respect of aircraft noise and the problems that are occurring around Sydney now which they chose to ignore at the time they were making their representations. One of the greatest complaints we had before us was the enormous disruption that came from jet aircraft coming in at night, being forced to abort their landings, going around at a lower altitude across all of populated Sydney and nobody explaining what had happened. We had several cases where one got the impression that this was happening every week when in fact it had happened nine times in three years.

So we have recommended a provision, and the government has picked this up in the bill that is now before us, that in the circumstance where an aborted landing takes place—or a go-around, as it is called—the airline concerned must notify the required person or the registered authority of the circumstances. People will understand if it happened in the cause of safety—if the aircraft was on descent and an event occurred that made it in the interest of the safety of passengers on board for the aircraft to abort the landing—but they must be told promptly what has taken place.

If, on the other hand, the pilot chose to come in, in contravention of advice that weather conditions may not have been acceptable, then let the airline wear it. Either way, the airlines have a responsibility now to explain what their operations are. Those associated with the industry have to explain what their operations are and they similarly have to share responsibility for the disturbance that is being inflicted upon the people who live in the vicinity of the airport. I commend the bill to the House. I am very pleased, on behalf of our committee, to express our appreciation of the government for the strong and positive response, particularly by the minister, they have given to the recommendations and the advice in the report. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995 arises out of my suggestion that the private member's bill of the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), which was introduced into the House in June, was insufficient in that it chose to legislate the existing curfew regulations without attempting to improve the situation or to tackle the difficult problem of the existing shoulder period. I recommended that the bill be sent for discussion to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, with a view to its being able to tighten the curfew provisions.

PARA.TAB: After examining the legislation with its inadequacies—namely, the flight quotas, the shoulder periods, the poor drafting concerning lack of community consultation, and inadequate penalties—I realised that the bill could not be successfully amended without the entire legislation being referred to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure.

It is very interesting to note at this stage that the Leader of the Opposition has been talking about moving an amendment regarding the east-west runway. He also talked about it at the time his bill was in the House. But I notice that he did not bother to move it at that stage because he did not want the transport committee to examine that proposition. We would then have seen just how fraudulent it is.

I requested that the Morris committee report back to the parliament by 31 August so that no time would be lost in investigating this issue. This has occurred. The government has had several weeks to reflect, and its response to these issues is raised in the bill that we have before us today.

This is a significantly improved bill from that which was proposed by the member for Bennelong. The new restrictions include: a reduction in quotas for international passenger movements during the curfew shoulder periods—5 a.m. to 6 a.m. and 11 p.m. to midnight; a requirement that each such movement be subject to individual vetting by the Department of Transport; and a requirement that all these movements be fully justified.

On Saturdays and Sundays aircraft operations from 6 a.m. to 7 a.m. and 10 p.m. to 11 p.m. will be required to take-off and land over Botany Bay, unless weather and traffic density prevent safe operations over water. For a normal weeknight, all departures after 10.45 p.m. will be required to take-off over Botany Bay to ensure aircraft are well clear of residential suburbs by 11 p.m. Large propeller-driven aircraft with over 34,000 kilograms maximum take-off weight will no longer be able to operate during the curfew.

Comprehensive consultation procedures will now allow wider community input into curfew decisions, and there will now be a requirement for full public scrutiny of any proposal to amend the curfew legislation. The penalties for curfew breaches will increase from the existing $25,000 to a maximum of $100,000.

A number of other issues have been raised, such as reverse thrust of aircraft. Operators have to give detailed information as to why they would use reverse thrust, and if they do use it an explanation has to be given within seven days. I would also like to talk about the reduced movements. In the shoulder periods that I have often referred to, 14 landings or take-offs would occur during any week between 11 p.m. and midnight. As a result of this legislation, there will be a maximum of four on any night and no more than 35 landings during any week between 5 a.m. and 6 a.m. Therefore, there will be a maximum of seven per day.

Consistent with the proposal from the House of Representatives standing committee, the bill allows the regulations to lower but not to increase the permitted number of movements. In fact, there has been a decrease in the number of international flights of seven per week. There is also the recommendation that any flights outside the curfew go to Badgerys Creek airport when it is up and running.

I have noted with interest the member for Bennelong putting out press releases last week announcing that he was going to move an amendment to this bill. He was challenging me, as the member for Lowe, as to what I was going to do about this. He was taunting me, telling me what I should do. He was challenging me: should I cross the floor; should I support my party or should I look after my constituents? What an absolute hypocrite this man is. He knows full well that the opening of the east-west runway will do nothing for his people or my people.
The Leader of the Opposition knows the reason why it should not progress. In February 1989 he was taunting the government that we should proceed with the third runway. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the interests of safety, airport facilities should be upgraded immediately including the construction of the third runway. The current congestion at the airport is causing increased noise pollution and becoming a serious threat both to travellers and local residents. The Government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. The risk must be averted.
He was in favour of it then because he knew that Kingsford Smith airport was at maximum capacity with 55 movements an hour.

PARA.TAB: A number of submissions have been made to the Senate committee of inquiry that has been looking at this issue. It is safe to run cross-runways, but at what capacity? We know that it is safe at 55 movements an hour because we have had that before. In 1989 the decision was made to build a third runway at the urging of not only the Leader of the Opposition but many other members of the opposition. I have some lovely quotes to remind those opposite of what they said about it in those days. It was urged that we needed to up the capacity. The industry demanded it. We all know that the industry is growing at an enormous rate. We were told that we had to have a third runway to deal with the traffic. We had to have a maximum capacity on parallel runways of 85 movements an hour. The difficulty is that you cannot run cross-runways at 85 movements an hour. What is John Howard talking about? Certainly all the safety people say that. I have a good quote from the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He should hang around a bit and we will come back to him later. The member for Bennelong knows full well that by opening the east-west runway to jet traffic you cannot safely have 85 movements an hour. I accept that you can have 55 movements an hour. But what do you do with the third runway? Perhaps you could use it for drag racing or rollerblading. Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition might have some other suggestion for its use rather than waste the $500 million involved.

The Leader of the Opposition knew that congestion was going to arise. He knew that we had to have some other facility to deal with the problem. Personally, I wish we had not gone ahead with the third runway at Kingsford Smith airport. Nevertheless, we have, and now we are left with the legacy and we have to try to find some way to resolve the problem for the people living under the flight path. Anyone who suggests that the honourable member for Bennelong—if he were in the position to do so—would do more than simply open the east-west runway for propeller-driven aircraft is fooling himself or herself. If the propeller-driven aircraft are put on the stub of the east-west runway—and that is not on an intersecting runway—it could be done safely. However, that means you up the capacity of Kingsford Smith airport once again and increase movements from 85 to closer to 95 or 100 per hour.

That means that the slots for the jets on the north-south runway that fly over my constituents and over the member for Bennelong's constituents will be opened up for more jets and more noise. If I believed for one moment that there was a legitimate proposition of opening the east-west runway, sharing the pain, keeping the capacity, and doing it safely, I would cross the floor. But those opposite are hypocrites and they know darn well that it cannot be done. The opposition is playing for political mileage and we are not going to be fooled by it.

Let us get back to some of these great quotes from the past about why we had to have the third runway in the first place. On 21 March 1989 in an interview with Mike Carlton on radio station 2GB the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: I grew up under the flight paths in the area of St George of Sydney and know something of the politics of that area and I've always regarded the issue as being grossly exaggerated in terms of the impact on local residents. There are a limited number of people who are affected by aircraft noise. The great bulk of them are only mildly affected and in any event bought their houses knowing full well that they were under flight paths. In any event there are many sections of my electorate in areas like Lane Cove and Hunters Hill that have just as much aircraft noise and are as frequently under flight paths as people living near the airport.
The interviewer said:
They may in fact get less if the third runway is built—the people around Lane Cove.
John Howard responded:

Many people will because you'll have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming. Our policy is to build it. That has been our policy for the past six and a half years.
He was not alone: the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) also said, on 2 October 1991:

The Federal Government must ignore the advice of the NSW Opposition leader, Bob Carr, and order the immediate commencement of Sydney's third runway . . . . If Mr Carr was in charge of our nation's development we'd still be living in caves.
He also said, on 3 October 1991:

The critics of the EIS are acting like spoilt children. They didn't get what they wanted from the study and are now threatening to halt the project either in the courts or in cabinet. This is a dangerously short-sighted view which pays no attention to the significant social and economic benefits that the third runway will bring.
I am glad to see that the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) is in the chamber because I have a quote from him. On 13 January 1991 he said:

. . . the recently completed draft Environmental Impact Study . . . was prepared on some of the most exacting grounds yet seen in Australia. The EIS allows for three times the normal period for public input; provides $100,000 for groups opposed to the Third Runway to prepare submissions, and; has established a large number of Government funded information booths to display the EIS.
Mr Cadman branded the opponents of the third runway as `short-sighted'. He said:
Rather than see the irrefutable merits of the third runway, they have put self interest before Australia's long-term national interests, and they are jeopardising the long-term safety of travellers.
I also quote the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). On 20 February 1989 he said:
A third runway would increase the airport's capacity by as much as 40 percent and significantly ease congestion and safety worries . . .
He told a conference:
. . . the coalition stood by its cast iron guarantee that a third runway would be built at Sydney Airport as soon as it was elected to government.

We come back to John Howard again. It is quite difficult to understand the coalition's support for the reintroduction of cross-runway operations at Sydney airport given the strong safety reasons that they have put forward in the past for getting rid of them and in supporting parallel operations. On 8 February 1989 John Howard said:
In the interests of safety, airport facilities should be upgraded immediately, including the construction of a third runway.
The current congestion at the airport is causing increased noise pollution and becoming a serious threat both to travellers and to local residents.
The Government is playing carelessly with a situation that could too easily result in a major tragedy. This risk must be averted.
The member for Hume (Mr Sharp), on 14 December 1988, said:
The government's indecision on the runway has put at risk the health of our flourishing tourist industry, the thousands of jobs it can provide, and the lives of both domestic and overseas travellers.
Isn't it interesting—the lives of people were being put at risk under the safety of this old parallel system. The honourable member continued:
The Government is ignoring the safety hazard the present chaotic conditions are presenting.
Finally, I quote the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). On 13 August 1991 he stated:

The Federal government must make three decisions. Firstly to accept the expert advice that the third runway is environmentally more friendly than the present two runway setup, secondly that safety is of paramount importance and finally that the vital tourist industry must no longer be choked off through lack of sensible economic thinking.

It is no wonder that ordinary people are becoming cynical about politicians. I refer to the deception that the honourable member for Bennelong is trying to put on people who are affected by the flight path noise. I am only too well aware of the flight path and what it represents to my people and what they have to endure in Drummoyne and also areas adjoining the flight path such as Five Dock and Haberfield. That is why I have taken such an active interest in the Sydney Airport Consultative Committee and am trying to bring about some real changes and improvements in the flight procedures and environmental concerns.

PARA.TAB: I notice that one of the submissions to the Senate committee inquiry by the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital Medical Board talks in detail about jet fuel emissions and the possible and additional known carcinogens and their impact on concentrated flight paths. I believe these environmental issues are very important and must be addressed. Their submission makes the point that the long-term solution will only be facilitated with a firm commitment to a major airport at Badgerys Creek, and I certainly endorse that.

I do note, however, that we need further environmental impact statements on the growth of Badgerys Creek—not only what was originally planned but the further extensions. The lesson that needs to be learned from KSA is the importance of how those environmental impact statements are carried out and consultation with people so that they know well in advance what is coming in their direction. But, certainly, it should be a 24-hour international airport.

I also lodged a submission to the Senate committee of inquiry. Basically, I tried to address the obvious point that people want to know whether there is a solution to Sydney's problems by flights taking off and landing over water without affecting people. I came to a conclusion that there probably was but that it would be a very expensive option. It would mean removing people who were in Kurnell and simply relocating them—and I am talking about 1,000 families. I know that the cost would be enormous, but we are being very short-sighted by not looking at an option when we have water there. Certainly it has been done in San Francisco and other places. However, this was not taken up. The idea with Kurnell was also to run an east-west flight path on Kurnell and to look at moving the oil refinery.

With regard to Sydney Harbour, I still believe we should look at the possibility of having flights coming down the coast, over the harbour and down either side of Balmain Peninsula. I notice in the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill one of the decisions made with regard to Kurnell is that there is a veering of the flight path to avoid the houses there. So I believe that the same logic could be applied to coming in around the harbour. It would mean that fewer people would be affected by noise—certainly the people whom I represent and all the people to the north and to the west. I look forward to the Senate committee's report to see what they come up with. That is something I will be fighting for because I believe that this is another option whereby you would not necessarily have to use the current parallel runways. Nevertheless, I say now what I said then about the east-west—and I have been consistent throughout—that many of my constituents have argued about the `share the pain' philosophy. That is very understandable, because when people are affected by noise they naturally grab at any straw to alleviate their pain. The idea of opening up the east-west runway has a lot of appeal, but it is only when you look at it that you realise that it just does not hold up. The truth is that, in the end, all we will be doing will be allowing the propeller-driven aircraft to go and not removing any of the jets. In fact, it will mean increased jet noise over the homes of the people whom I represent.

I would like to quote the views of a couple of people from different parts of industry on the parallel runways. The first is a media release on airlines endorsing the operational efficiency of the parallel runways. A joint press statement issued by Qantas and Ansett dated 18 September states:

SPEECH.PARA: We accept the advice from the regulatory authorities and from our technical experts that safety and efficiency would be diminished by permanently reopening the East West Runway to jet movements," they added. "While in practice it has never closed, and is used when prevailing weather does not permit parallel operations, the key point is that intersecting runways are inherently less efficient and less safe.
A media release dated 14 August 1995 by Air Services Australia states:

Parallel runways provide significantly higher capacity than intersecting runways and are the most effective means of meeting the growing demand for access to Australia's major international destinations.
Finally, I quote Hazelton Airlines, in case anyone is in any doubt about what I have said about propeller-driven aircraft. In December 1994 they said:
To give maximum capacity, it is imperative to open 07-25 runway for Regional Aircraft . . . that have a very low noise factor. In fact a bus on the road would make more noise.

PARA.TAB: (a) Every NON-JET aircraft taken out of the mainstream "traffic flow" allows more jet traffic onto 16/34 runways (there should not be a noise problem as this procedure has been used for many years).

SPEECH.PARA: So they are arguing that they can put them out over the east-west and they certainly can. But let nobody in the north-south affected by the flight paths be unaware of the fact that it would mean an increased number of jets. In conclusion, I believe that the flight movements at Kingsford Smith airport should be capped. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill that the government has brought in today is only in response to a piece of legislation proposed by the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard. The government has taken 12 years to even consider the problems of Sydney airport's needs and the movement of aircraft in the Sydney area. It is a surprising thing to the opposition that the government has taken their proposal, their legislation, their suggestion of putting in place by legislation a curfew at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport; that it has taken that initiative to produce from the government a report from a parliamentary committee and then the legislation preventing the flight of aircraft between the hours of 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. in the Sydney region. The fact of the matter is that if the person who prepared this report for the House of Representatives had been the Hon. Peter Morris, as the minister in charge of aviation in Australia, instead of Laurie and his truck—
—The honourable member will refer to the minister by his correct title.

—If, instead of the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, being in charge, Mr Morris had been in charge, we would have had quite a different result. There would have been care in the decision taking process. There would have been effective consultations with the community. There would have been a decision based on economic and environmental grounds, which would produce the best results for the city of Sydney.

PARA.TAB: The problem is the minister. He is under the thumb of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The Prime Minister got smart and thought that he would play games, not only with the flight paths of aircraft but, I contend, with aircraft safety in the way he interfered with the recommendations of the properly appointed authorities who were recommending continual use of the north-south runway out over Botany Bay, with occasional use of the east-west runway. Those have been the recognised industry conditions on which the construction of the third runway took place. That is why the opposition has supported this consistently and that is why, in government, with the Hon. Wal Fife as minister, we took the decision to build the third runway. It was simply because we knew it would alleviate the problem of sound pollution for thousands of people in the Sydney area.

The proposal was that aircraft would take off over Botany Bay and land over Botany Bay and, when weather conditions made it untenable to continue that process, the east-west runway would be used. It had not been contemplated, until the Prime Minister got into the act, that there would be take-offs and landings to the north of Kingsford Smith over the suburbs to the north of the north-south runway.

The Prime Minister is just too smart by half. He organised his friend the Minister for Transport to have a motorbike parked handy after a certain preselection in which there was some very unusual activity. In this instance, he has organised his friend again to fiddle with aircraft safety and with the general economic management of Mascot. Consistently we are hearing both the minister and members of the government saying, `Safety is a factor and it is impossible to build the numbers to a sufficient level unless we exclusively use the north-south runways.' I quote, for the benefit of the House, from an interview on 23 November 1994 between Kerry O'Brien, Geoff Parish and a number of others, including the minister, Mr Laurie Brereton MP. Mr Brereton says:

SPEECH.PARA: That means by the end of next year, they are not allowed to schedule more than 85 take-offs and landings in any one hour.
The minister is saying to Kerry O'Brien that the maximum that the north-south runway configuration will take is 85 take-offs and landings in any one hour. Further in the interview Kerry O'Brien says:
So presumably a significant part of that increased usage is from business people who are doing their work to boost our economy, but we can't accommodate them.
Minister Brereton responds:
Well, I think the economic recovery has certainly been a considerable factor—
He refuses to answer the question—
in this increased demand.
Later in that same interview Kerry O'Brien draws the minister's attention to several factors. I will start by quoting Minister Brereton, who states:

But if I can turn to the safety considerations which support the environmental approval, the Civil Aviation Authority have indicated to me that on safety grounds they would not be prepared to run a cross-runway while they are operating parallel runway operations.
Kerry O'Brien states:
But you would be aware of the study prepared for the FAC by an American consulting company called Flight Transportation Associates in 1989.
Minister Brereton responds:
As a matter of fact I am not, but tell me about it.
Kerry O'Brien says:
Well, it argues that you can operate all three runways, including east-west, safely and move up to 94 planes an hour.

Neither the minister nor anybody in the government has refuted the proposal that the FAC commissioned a firm of consultants to prepare an economic assessment of what is the best management of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. The best economic management of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport is to use all three runways. By doing so, it is possible to increase the number of movements by 15 or 20 per cent. The government has refused to acknowledge that. Instead, it has rushed headlong into the development of Badgerys Creek as an alternative.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us today to prevent aircraft flying at night-time is a reaction to the initiative taken by the Leader of the Opposition. So there we have the facts. It is possible for us to make greater use of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport, but the Prime Minister and his friend the Minister for Transport refuse to do so. They are prepared to dump this problem on a whole new section of Sydney that has never before experienced aircraft noise. This impost is damaging to the lifestyles, health and property valuations of people in areas such as Mascot and Rockdale, which are in the seats of the Minister for Transport and other members of the Labor Party. That process of development and lifestyle came about with the knowledge that Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport was there and operating. It has not affected lifestyles unless people were prepared to let that happen. It has not affected property values or business in any way unless people were unprepared for what has occurred there.

However, in the northern suburb of Hunters Hill, in the electorate of Mitchell, and in areas such as Carlingford and North Rocks, lifestyles have changed dramatically. Twenty-six miles out of Sydney, in the Carlingford-North Rocks area, which is at a high elevation because the topography rises the further west that you go in that part of Sydney, aircraft are now coming over homes at heights never dreamed of by the residents when they purchased those properties. Children, the elderly and the sick are being affected by a complete change of lifestyle—one that is endorsed by the current Minister for Transport.

I do not know how the Labor Party can defend this process of sudden change without any compensation or thought of the lifestyles of anybody. It is a sheer political decision based on the fact that they have the power and the right to make the decision. They have exercised that right despite the need for consultation and despite the reprise and the requests of others. If that is the selfish exercise of power that is being adopted by the Minister for Transport, he is setting a precedent which may seriously disadvantage him if others decide to act in the same way. It has not been the process of government, to my knowledge, for a minister to selfishly exercise power to advantage himself and disadvantage not a political opponent but hundreds of thousands of citizens who are residents of Sydney.

It is no wonder that people are steamed up, and no wonder that they turn out in force and with some violence against this ad hoc decision making, particularly when they know and understand that the FAC at its commissioned inquiry has established that the government made a wrong decision and is not making the best use of Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. We can go through the documents, through the process and through the story of what has happened at Sydney (Kingsford Smith), but the result is that Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, through his minister, has decided that he will change and disadvantage a large proportion of Sydney.

It has never been the argument of the coalition that that should occur; it has always been our argument that there needs to be a balance and a spreading of some of the disadvantage. I was amazed to find that there was a hotel constructed, quite out of the blue evidently, to the north of this shortened runway at Mascot, limiting its use completely. So the government has made a series of decisions which are faulty and not in the best interests of the people of Sydney, nor in the best interests of aircraft travel.

I refer to the submissions to the committee that has just conducted this inquiry and to the work done by the Hon. Peter Morris, who ought to have been the minister conducting this whole process but has not been. According to the submissions, the doctors at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital are finding it extremely difficult to carry on their tasks; patients and nurses are finding it difficult to communicate, and it is difficult to attract new staff. The care of people is mentioned in this way in the submission:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of such a noise level repeated every 2-3 minutes is clearly detrimental to good medical care . . . Sleep is essential for healing, both physical and psychological. It is simply not possible to provide medical care for seriously ill people in such an environment.

So we have a government without any care for the needs of Sydney, a government which for crass political purposes is making a decision that is demonstrably—economically, environmentally, health-wise; in every way that you can look at it—of least benefit to the people of Sydney. That is bad enough, but the people in my area have written hundreds of complaints about the change in their lifestyle. They are sick of the government, and they are just looking forward to the next election so they can clout a government that disregards the simple basics of consultation and communications.

PARA.TAB: The report presented by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure is heavily into communications and consultation because it knows how poor the minister has been in that process. One only has to read through the conclusions of that report to realise that, amongst their recommendations—many of which the government has decided to pick up—are recommendations initiated by the Leader of the Opposition but which, for the purposes of covering the tracks of the member for Lowe (Mrs Easson), were pushed off to a parliamentary committee. Surprise, surprise—the parliamentary committee, dominated by the Australian Labor Party, comes back with basically the same recommendations as Mr Howard had in his legislation, but of course it has now been laundered through a parliamentary committee.

Today the government brings this legislation to the House. When one looks at the committee recommendations, it is obvious that the committee felt that the communications process, the consultation with people, was extremely poor. One only has to look at the simple table of complaints about international passenger jet aircraft movements to realise the seriousness of the situation.

The number of complaints in the three years under examination by the committee—that is, June 1991 to June 1994—totalled 327. Two-thirds of those complaints came from the north. There is a part for the government to play to do something about it, but it will not play it. It will put in place a curfew when it could be making a totally better use of Mascot by opening up the east-west runway. That is an essential thing to happen.

I wish to say something about what is happening in the relationship between these proposals and Badgerys Creek. It appears that the government has decided to go ahead with Badgerys Creek. The minister is optimistic about having the runway open by the end of 1999. That is the height of expectations and cannot be met. It is so optimistic that I do not believe the infrastructure of rail, road and airport, linked together with Sydney's Kingsford Smith, can possibly be completed by the end of 1999.

I have asked the minister to provide for me a detailed summary of the works program to achieve this process. The minister keeps telling me that before Badgerys Creek can go ahead there will be a full environmental and economic study about how it will be done. That has not even started. The people in western Sydney are asking when the government is going to get active in this regard, when the government will do something and when the government will start communicating with them about their intentions for Badgerys Creek. The people of my electorate and the electorates nearby in western Sydney are looking down the barrel of the gun of aircraft noise and no curfew. The legislation we are considering today puts into law the fact that there will be no curfew at Sydney West airport. This is the first time that Sydney West will have no curfew.

I do not know whether the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott) was involved in that decision. It would be very interesting, in light of his statements to the local press in the area, to see whether he stands by this legislation, which says that the curfew will not apply in Sydney West. Aircraft directed to Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport after 11 o'clock will be diverted to land at Sydney West. That is the intention of the legislation.

I know that the member and other members in the west have expressed their concern about what are going to be the sound footprints for Badgerys Creek when it opens up. In some areas, they face the prospect of the double whammy of Badgerys Creek coming on one side of them and Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport coming on the other side. The crossover point is along the ridge of Pennant Hills Road in Sydney. As best we can determine, for those residents on that elevated area, there will be noise pollution from both Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport and Badgerys Creek.

It is up to the government to come clean. All its constituents are in western Sydney. It claims to represent them, yet it treats them like mushrooms. It will not communicate with them. There are ministers and parliamentary secretaries there. None of them can get a statement out of the government. None can provide effective information about the intentions of the government. None can find out what sorts of aircraft will fly, except we know that they will be neither fully international nor fully domestic aircraft. It will be a hybrid runway there. At some time in the future we will get full aircraft use of it.

The government claims that it will be one of the big boosts for western Sydney in employment coming up to the Sydney Olympics in the year 2000. I accuse the government of being unprepared for the Olympics. I condemn the government for the lack of consultation and information that they are providing to the residents of western Sydney both in the construction and use of Badgerys Creek or Sydney West. I particularly condemn them for their failure to alleviate the problems over north-western Sydney which have been created by the abuse of the minister's power with regard to Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport. Those elevated areas of Sydney are copping as much noise as many areas closer to the airport. Because of their elevation, the topography and the air movement around Sydney, on still nights—periods when the residents of those areas have been used to rest and quiet—the rest and quiet of residents has been disturbed by the crass political manipulations of aircraft movements, safety and economy by the Minister for Transport and the Prime Minister.

They are not fit to govern because they do not trust the people. They will not communicate with the people. Neither will they do anything to make a decision that is going to be in the best interests of all the people of Sydney. Instead, they bring in paltry legislation and refuse to open that east-west runway. It is time they looked at the total picture and came up with a decision that was in the interests of all the residents of the Sydney area.
