TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in support of the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill, particularly to attempt to put into proper context this rewriting of history we have heard in the course of the debate today from some of the speakers from the opposition. The government's considered response to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure—the Morris committee—on the airport curfew certainly imposes much tougher restrictions than those that were the subject of the original private member's bill moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

PARA.TAB: There are a number of provisions, and for the record it is worth restating a few of them. First of all, the new restrictions include a reduction in quotas for international passenger movements during the curfew shoulder periods—that is, from 5 a.m. to 6 a.m. and from 11 p.m. to midnight—and a requirement that each such movement be subject to individual vetting by the Department of Transport. There will be further restrictions in relation to Saturdays and Sundays. Aircraft operations between 6 a.m. and 7 a.m. and between 10 p.m. and 11 p.m. will be required to take off and land over Botany Bay unless weather and traffic density prevent safe operations over water. All departures after 10.45 p.m. will be required to take off over Botany Bay to ensure aircraft are well clear of residential suburbs by 11 p.m.

Large propeller-driven aircraft over 34,000 kilograms maximum take-off weight will no longer be able to operate during the curfew period. Comprehensive consultation procedures will now allow much wider community input into curfew decisions. There will be full public scrutiny of any proposals to amend the curfew legislation. Of course, there will be an increase in the penalty provisions for curfew breaches from the existing $25,000 to $100,000.

All of these new restrictions have come about because the government has been going through a very comprehensive process following the opening of the third runway and all of the contingent issues that have arisen since that time. In relation to consultation, the processes have improved. I am one who believes that, in terms of consultation, the original processes that led to the third runway decision were totally inadequate. I certainly hold the view that those who clamoured for the building of the third runway and to heck with the consequences were totally irresponsible in the course of action they followed to pursue that objective.

It is worth going back over the record to see who were the big advocates to build a third runway at any consequence, who kept forcing this issue along and who are now misrepresenting the impacts of the original EIS on the third runway. A great many of them sit opposite us. The issue was raised by the Leader of the Opposition in February 1989; the shadow minister for transport, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), in December 1988; and the previous speaker, the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), in January 1991. Given the speech we have just heard, it is interesting that on 11 January 1991 the member for Mitchell said:

SPEECH.PARA: Without a start on the third runway this year, genuine safety problems would develop due to increased congestion on the current runways. The politicians advocating for cancellation of the third runway project should be more concerned about the genuine safety and environmental issues for their constituents rather than phoney political points.

Now we are getting the phoney political points. They are coming from over that side of the chamber. The clear implication of the fact that a proper process was not followed, that there was not a proper understanding of the potential impacts of the building of the third runway in terms of not only air safety but also environmental impacts across Sydney, has now come home to roost.

PARA.TAB: The EIS at that time did identify that there would be a change with the parallel operation of the two north-south runways. It was made clear in the EIS that there were going to be some losers but many winners in noise impact. The Liberal state government of the time came out publicly and said that the EIS highlighted that the number of people seriously affected would reduce from 54,700 to 26,900 and those moderately affected would reduce from 170,000 to 82,000. Those things were known and highlighted as a virtue by the Liberal state government under Nick Greiner back in 1990.

How was the change in noise impact going to occur? It was going to occur because of the greatly diminished impact of the third runway. It was only going to be used when the wind velocity was such that it needed to be used for safety reasons and when the use of the two parallel north-south runways was prohibited. Those things were known. Now we are told, `Yes that was true. The state government made those claims. That was in the EIS.'

Apparently, the Leader of the Opposition did not read the studies and was not aware of that because he kept advocating the building of the third runway at all cost. Admittedly, the boundaries of the Bennelong electorate have changed since that time. The Leader of the Opposition now pretends that a solution to Sydney's aircraft noise problems would be a sharing of the pain, as he describes it.

I am certainly one who thinks there needs to be better planning of the overall aviation needs of Sydney. I do not think the third runway was the right solution to those problems, but a slogan about sharing the pain is not going to change any of the issues. We need to make sure at this stage that there is a comprehensive plan recognising where the shortcomings were in the past. We need to recognise that the curfew restrictions at Kingsford Smith airport need to be toughened up dramatically.

As a result of the recommendations of the Morris committee, the parliament is now in a position to proceed vigorously to ensure that there is a toughening up of the curfew restrictions. Frankly, many of the things that have been allowed to occur at Kingsford Smith airport are unacceptable to residents in my electorate and many other electorates.

Trying to get a solution to the problem and a proper understanding of those issues has been well nigh impossible. Even getting decent noise monitoring equipment into parts of Sydney which the original EIS said were not going to be affected by noise has proved impossible. When you ask the authorities for information on this, that proves very difficult as well.

The reason all that has occurred is that there has not been adequate consultation in the past. There has not been a process that has genuinely involved the people of Sydney in proper airport planning. The Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has quite rightly brought forward the curfew bill at this stage as a very important part of trying to address some of the core concerns that residents throughout Sydney have with regard to the level of aircraft noise in Sydney.

For anybody to suggest that the reopening of the east-west runway is going to solve those problems is not right. Everybody knows that that will mean that there will be more prop aircraft on the east-west runway and more jets thundering up and down the north-south corridors—the very issue that is causing concern to the residents who ring me. The Leader of the Opposition actually wants to maximise this problem and perhaps have 10 additional jet movements an hour to make the problem more acute than it already is for the residents of Sydney.

That is not a solution to the air traffic needs of Sydney. It is not a solution to the growth in air traffic that is going to go through Sydney in the years ahead. We need long-term, comprehensive, properly planned and well-considered solutions. There was agitation from all sorts of vested interests in the lead-up to the building of the third runway, whether from the tourism industry or other industries. This agitation was aided and abetted and actively connived in by the airlines and the FAC and others all played their part in encouraging that ill-considered, ill-conceived approach to aircraft planning in Sydney.

Those things need to be treated in a different fashion in the future. That is the lesson from what has occurred. This curfew bill is one of the processes that needs to be followed to remedy those short-sighted planning processes of the past. I come back to the opposition's humbug on the issue which is that we should reopen the east-west runway. The consequence of that would be more jet noise over those same suburbs that the member for the Mitchell and others have talked about in this debate.

If there is any doubt about that, members should look at what Hazelton Airlines said its approach is to the issue. They said they want to get the prop aircraft back on the east-west runway, and the rest of the airline industry said, `You beaut. That means we can get more jets up and down the north-south corridor.' All of those things are unacceptable. A better solution needs to be found.

The member for Mitchell, as I said, back in 1991 was one of those agitating for the building of the third runway. Now we have a discussion today that brings in the issue of Badgerys Creek. I want to spend a little time referring to that as well. If we do not learn the lessons of the appalling planning process that has occurred in relation to consultation and development of the airport at Mascot in the way we develop Badgerys Creek airport, then the whole community is entitled to say that there is something dramatically wrong.

The government has made it clear that in the development of Badgerys Creek it is going to ensure a process is followed that gives proper community consultation and takes full account of the need to update the whole environmental process that was the subject of the original EIS for Badgerys Creek in 1985. I and a number of my colleagues have been pressing for that to occur. There has been a series of developments in relation to the land around Badgerys Creek in the last 10 years and, just as importantly, the experience of what has occurred at Sydney airport can be learned from in the planning of Badgerys Creek.

In my view, the noise monitoring ANEF arrangements that were adopted as the model in the original EIS for Kingsford Smith airport have been shown to be totally inadequate. Areas such as parts of Parramatta were not incorporated into noise corridors of any significant note in relation to the third runway, yet we are still getting that noise level. On the development of the original EIS for Badgerys Creek, some of the same assumptions in relation to noise contours were repeated.

The minister has given an assurance that there will be that updating of the process of the EIS—full consultation not only on the noise issues but also on the broader environmental issues of water quality and other issues that go to the development of a new airport at Badgerys Creek. A clear understanding has been achieved with the minister that there will be a strong proposition that movement in and out of Badgerys Creek at night will be out to the south-west through a corridor which has not had the population, and therefore does not have the same environmental or residential amenity concerns, that occurs as you move back from the north-east of the airport at Badgerys Creek.

We have also had a clear commitment from the minister to make sure there is consultation about the flight path planning process, to again ensure that every effort is made to minimise the potential impacts on residents through western Sydney from the development of the airport. In addition, in recent times, the government has made commitments to build the major road infrastructure, with the western orbital link and the widening of Elizabeth Drive, to provide the proper road infrastructure to the airport, and then to link that back in to the main road link back to Sydney from the west, the M4.

It is also critical—and the government has agreed it is very important—that the rail link to Badgerys Creek should proceed as soon as possible. Up to this stage, the state government has not been willing to commit the resources to proceed with that rail link to Badgerys Creek. My view is that to plan Badgerys Creek effectively, to make sure not only in terms of the airport but in terms of the other infrastructure that will develop in the region, and to meet the public transport needs of western Sydney to and from Badgerys Creek, it will be critical that we get a proper road link to Badgerys Creek as part of the airport development and also a comprehensive rail link that links back to the western line.

All of those things must proceed if we are going to ensure that we have learned the lessons from the problems associated with Kingsford Smith airport. It is up to the parliament to ensure—not only in passing this legislation, because that does toughen up the curfew requirements as far as Kingsford Smith airport is concerned, but as we come through the range of issues relating to Badgerys Creek—that we make sure all of the residents of Sydney do not have additional aircraft noise problems visited upon them and that there is proper planning of the integration of air traffic to the two airports as that emerges.

The Leader of the Opposition on the one hand came in today and talked about the reopening of the east-west runway. On the other hand, he is sending out mail around his electorate saying, `Not only have we got to reopen the east-west runway but we have got to fast-track Badgerys Creek.' There is no commitment in the material he is sending out to his electorate to say, `We have to make sure that we overcome the problems about the environmental concerns and other important issues relating to transport infrastructure and the like and that we do not repeat the problems of KSA at Badgerys Creek.'

None of those things are covered. All he says is that they will fast-track Badgerys Creek and reopen the east-west runway. None of the other important safeguards, which the residents in western Sydney are concerned about and that the member for Mitchell referred to, were mentioned. They are the things that need to be incorporated as part of a comprehensive package to meet the air safety needs of Sydney in the years to come.

During the debate reference has also been made to this whole question of simultaneous operations with the parallel runways and the east-west runway arrangement. People are saying that there is no safety issue involved. They dismiss experts such as Dr Ratner, who has looked at this issue extensively and said that simultaneous operations inevitably increase the risks, particularly as the volume of traffic grows through the airport. The Leader of the Opposition says, `We all know that that is not true. No-one should take any notice of those sorts of things.'

Even at the busiest airport in the world, Heathrow in London, where there are two parallel runways and the runway that operates as a cross-runway, the cross-runway is used 1 1/2 per cent of the time. Why is it just 1 1/2 per cent of the time? It is not just because of wind considerations. The authorities at Heathrow have been exploring all of the options to ensure they have the best possible air safety at Heathrow. What conclusion have they come to? That parallel runways operations are far safer operations than cross-runway operations. A similar situation arises at Los Angeles airport where there are four parallel runways and there is not a cross-runway. Again, the authorities at that very busy airport are saying, `We know that is the safest way of having air safety ensured.'

There have been discussions about building a further runway at Heathrow airport, although those discussions have not led anywhere at this stage. Again, the implication from what is being done is that we should not jeopardise air safety in whatever approach is taken and that additional cross-runway arrangements would only serve to intensify the risk at a very busy airport because of simultaneous type operations.

In relation to Sydney airport, the EIS consistently made clear that the development of the parallel runway arrangements was superior in terms of air safety to the alternative approaches. If we are worried about sharing the noise, we are surely worried about making sure that we just do not increase the number of jets that move up and down the north-south corridors in the way that the Leader of the Opposition's proposal would inevitably lead to. It is beyond comprehension that, in this day and age, we would actually see such a bandaid as a solution to a very major problem that very many people in Sydney are raising as a legitimate concern.

We need strong, concerted action starting with the stronger curfew measures introduced by the government. It is worth noting again that the Leader of the Opposition's original bill, which came in as a private member's bill, did not have the strong commitments as far as the shoulder periods are concerned. It did not have the increased penalties and the tougher regime to ensure tougher compliance with the airport curfew. It did not include any additional provisions relating to Saturday and Sunday mornings and evenings to try to increase the level of comfort and lower the level of noise that residents were feeling throughout the region.

When many of the authorities raised these issues, all we had was this bland statement: `Well, those things just don't count. This is just a decision being made to protect one or two.' We need, first of all, to get the airport curfew measures applied rigidly by the authorities and to make sure that there is proper compliance with those measures. That is one of the areas where I think there has been a lack of effort put in until very recent times.

It is clear that many aircraft are still not conforming as rigorously as they should be with the agreed flight path corridors. It is clear that major work still needs to be done in areas that were outside the original study into noise impacts, because those impacts are real. We need to look at all the alternatives so that we get a better operation in terms of air safety and in having less impact on the residents of Sydney who are being severely affected by this problem of aircraft noise. The government has a real solution to address those issues. We should focus on that rather than the sort of sloganising that we have had from opposition speakers today.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that the government has played confuse and abuse for too long. It is time that we sought equity and fairness as the principles that deal with the question of noise. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that indicate that it is not possible to allow the Australian economy to grow strong enough or long enough to reduce unemployment significantly? What is the government's response to these reports?

—I thank the member for his question. I must say that it is, of course, an allegation that is continually coming from the opposition. And the Leader of the Opposition said words to that effect today in, I think, an interview with 2GB. But it is a common refrain that this government has failed on economic growth and has not been able to produce sufficient growth to bring unemployment down significantly.

PARA.TAB: I think, actually, the Leader of the Opposition must be confusing the situation today with when he was in office because that was certainly a true description of what happened when he was in office—when he had high inflation, high unemployment and very little economic growth. And his record stands in sharp contrast with that of this government.

We certainly have delivered on economic growth. The June quarter national accounts, as members are aware, showed us that we had had 16 quarters of consecutive economic growth which equalled the previous record. We can be confident that in September we will go beyond that and break that record by establishing 17 quarters and we can expect to go on from there.

Over the last three years economic growth has averaged four per cent—in fact, just over four per cent—and the unemployment rate has fallen by three per cent since October 1993. So where is this suggestion coming from, in terms of any analysis of the facts, about inability to obtain growth, inability to bring the unemployment rate down? It has been happening in spades in the last two or three years—happening in spades. The consensus amongst private sector forecasters is that growth is going to continue for the foreseeable future.

The recent survey by Consensus Economics—this is a London based body which polls private sector forecasters—asked respondents to forecast quarterly growth for Australia out to the June quarter of 1997. Those respondents expect quarterly growth to remain positive over that entire period. In other words, they are saying that they expect the Australian economy to show continuous growth for at least 24 quarters. That is six years of continuous growth, and I remind the House that the best that the Australian economy achieved when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer for 5 1/4 years was five quarters of consecutive growth. But in the view of the Consensus Economics respondents, we are set for six years of continuous economic growth.

In fact, if you look back at the record of the Leader of the Opposition over his whole period in office as Treasurer, economic growth averaged 2.6 per cent. For us it has been 3 1/2 per cent—so virtually a one per cent increase. If we had simply maintained the Leader of the Opposition's rate of growth when he was Treasurer, Australia's GDP today would be some $45 billion less than it currently is. Our growth performance compares very well with that of other industrialised countries. Over the last 12 years the average GDP growth across 25 OECD countries has been 2 3/4 per cent—that is the average for all the Western industrialised countries. Ours has been 3 1/2 per cent, so we have three-quarters of a per cent better than the OECD average.

The latest OECD economic outlook forecast that this good performance will continue. It said that we were the second fastest OECD growth economy in 1994. They expect us to be the fifth fastest in 1995 and the fourth fastest in 1996. So where is this inability to generate growth?

Of course, the latest poll by the Economist, which is much referred to by the opposition for some purposes in terms of these tables at the back of the Economist, has a table which shows growth amongst the 15 most advanced industrial countries. That shows that, according to their respondents, in 1995 the second fastest growth country will be Australia. And for 1996 the same thing again—they expect us again to be the second fastest.

Wherever you turn in terms of what the forecasters are saying, be it the OECD, be it the Economist, be it Consensus Economics, you see this picture of Australia being expected to do exceedingly well in economic growth this year and next year. All this talk about there being an inability of Australia to grow, to generate jobs and to get unemployment down is just so much poppycock.

The benefits are flowing through to ordinary Australian households, principally and obviously through employment which has grown by 330,000 in the last 12 months. That is an annual growth rate of over four per cent. As you know, we promised at least 500,000 jobs at the last election. We have created 670,000 so far, with more to come. Over our period in office, the average growth in employment has been 2.3 per cent per annum. That is our employment rate of growth.

You know what the Leader of the Opposition's record was when he was Treasurer—a miserable 0.8 per cent, about one-third of our average rate of growth. In his five years in office, he created fewer jobs than we created in the last 12 months. That just shows how hopelessly inadequate the opposition was at developing employment growth. Of course, our two million jobs represent a very substantial increase in employment. When we got into office, Australia had been a nation for almost 200 years. We had a little over six million jobs. We had an additional two million in the next 12 years, which I think gives some idea of the level of that achievement.

Real household disposable income has also increased, so the benefits of growth are clearly coming through in terms of increased income. We have seen real household disposable income per capita grow by 1.9 per cent over the last 12 months, an average since we have been in office of 1.6 per cent compared with the average, when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer, of just one per cent.

Wherever you look, be it growth, be it employment, be it real household disposable incomes, quite clearly this government is incredibly superior to its predecessor, when the now Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer. He has a record—an economic record—and it is one he should be ashamed of, because it was a paltry, pathetic record and one which certainly does not qualify him to take over the job in the future. This government has delivered strong growth with low inflation. It is sustainable growth which will go on delivering high incomes and more jobs to Australians in years to come. John Howard could never deliver that.

We are also going to halve the size of the act by rewriting the tax laws. In addition, the commissioner's tax liaison group meets regularly with top tax professionals who put issues such as compliance costs directly to the commissioner. The tax office is also working with small business to see whether there are ways in which we can lower compliance costs for small business, not only for federal government taxes but also for state taxes. PARA.TAB: In relation to the second part of the question, I have seen calls to lower the costs of complying with tax laws. In fact, in a speech on 19 September the shadow Treasurer had this to say, and I will read out part of it: `We do not propose to abolish the FBT.' Thank goodness for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Because you opposed it when we introduced it; you remember that. `Our aim is to simplify its operation'—

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is addressed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the speech by the managing director of Standard and Poor's 10 days ago when he stated that Australia ranked 47 out of 51 countries, rated in terms of net external debt to exports. I ask the Treasurer: does he accept the contentions of the managing director that, firstly, Australia's position is very unfavourable compared with other countries; secondly, that this is an unfavourable feature of Australia's overall creditworthiness; thirdly, that it places Australia in a position where it is much more susceptible to international trends and preferences; and, finally, that it restricts flexibility in domestic economic management? Or is it the deep intellectual position of the Treasurer that the managing director of Standard and Poor's also gets up every morning and sucks on a lemon?

—I have seen that speech and read it, and I appreciate what is in it. In making those observations, the managing director of Standard and Poor's in Australia was demonstrating the factors which can go into a decision about the ratings of particular countries and the implications of them for other borrowers in that country.
—Other!

—Other borrowers. He was making the point that Australia's sovereign rating—that is, the rating of the Australian government—sets a ceiling above which no other borrower can go. But he said that very few others are actually affected by that. Only two of them were in the private sector, and they were multinationals. In other words, he was saying that this was not really a problem in terms of the private sector seeking to borrow overseas and being faced with a lesser rating achievement than they would be able to achieve in their own right. All of that makes quite good sense, and we certainly have no objection to it.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the issue about the rating of the country, he was saying that various factors go into that. Of course, they do. We all know that Australia, at AA, is not at the top rate. The top rate is AAA. There is then AA+ and AA. Of course, there are many countries around that level and many countries below that level. Many are way below the level that we are at. In deciding those ratings, the rating agencies obviously look at many factors. They look at the issues mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition in his question, such as the foreign debt issue or the current account. They also look at inflation performance, the general economic performance of the country and levels of government debt. These are all the sorts of issues which are taken into account by the rating agencies in deciding what the appropriate rating should be.

In deciding our rating, both Moody's and Standard and Poor's look at a variety of matters. Included amongst them are foreign debt and the current account. In deciding what impact that has on Australia, there is reason on the part of the opposition to have some caution in assuming that this means some tremendous increased burden on Australia in terms of higher interest rates. Obviously, the lower rating means that when the Australian government goes to borrow overseas we will be faced with some kind of premium that we would otherwise not have. The question is what the size of that premium is.

In the FitzGerald report, Dr FitzGerald had a list of premiums for various countries. He showed that Australia's premium was something in the order of 0.5 per cent, as I recall it. Since then, Treasury has done some further calculations to assess what the appropriate premium would be today. I notice that Dr FitzGerald said in an article the other day that the premium probably would have increased since the time of his report, but all the evidence is that it has not increased. In fact, it has reduced.

The information I have from Treasury is that if the Australian government borrowed money in America we would have to pay a higher interest rate because of our sovereign debt rating at AA. The assessment of that is that, instead of the premium being the 0.5 per cent talked about by Dr FitzGerald, it would be 0.09 per cent. The Australian government is not borrowing in America or anywhere else. We are not borrowing overseas. We have not done so since 1987. If we were to do so, that is Treasury's assessment of what the premium would be, because we have a AA rating rather than a AAA rating. It would be 0.09 per cent based on all the factors. That less than 0.1 per cent is for government borrowings.

The opposition make some enormous leap from there to say that because there would be such a premium, albeit minuscule, there would then be some translation into mortgage interest rates, by a mechanism they still have not described, which would mean that Australian mortgage payers would be paying much more in interest rates. It is a total non sequitur. Firstly, the evidence is that the premium is extremely small in terms of the impact of our lower rating. Secondly, the step from there to saying that mortgage interest rates would be higher is one which they have not in any way shown to be the case.

The opposition is not getting anywhere in terms of this argument. Until you tell us what the link is between this and mortgage interest rates and show us that that is the case, you have no case to prove your allegation, which I say is totally and utterly false.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Human Services and Health. It refers to Australia's health system and the consequences for Australians, particularly Australian families, of cuts to hospital and health services in South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Are those cuts consistent with the direction of the federal government's national health strategy; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. He has an obvious interest in this matter, as do other members. I do not think the opposition fully understand that the commitment to Medicare which they claim to have made commits them, amongst other things, to proper funding of our public hospital system.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, their colleagues in the state governments which are run by conservative parties show that they do not understand it. The most recent and drastic example is in South Australia where there have been very substantial cuts in public hospital funding, to the extent that the media now report it as a hospital cash crisis, following similar moves in Victoria.

There was an emergency meeting last week of South Australian public hospital administrators because of this cash crisis. Budget cuts in South Australian hospitals are as follows: the Royal Adelaide Hospital, down by $12 million; the Flinders Medical Centre, down by $10 million; the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, down by $8 million; the women's and children's hospital in Adelaide, down by $6.9 million. That is the sort of commitment to Medicare that we are seeing from conservative governments around the country, in South Australia in particular. The result of this is bed closures, a loss of services and a loss of hundreds of jobs. If that is a commitment to Medicare, you need to re-examine it.

Commonwealth funding in South Australia is not responsible for this situation. Under the Medicare agreements there was some $346 million in 1993, rising to some $434 million in 1995. For members' interests, that is an increase of 25 per cent over that period. At the same time, the South Australian government is slashing funds for hospitals. The effects of this can be seen already. A letter in the Advertiser recently, headed `Something sadly wrong in this state', reads as follows:
My daughter recently had a baby at 4.30 am at a major public hospital in Adelaide. We visited her then and made a return visit at 2 pm, only to find her nursing her baby in the visitors' lounge—

ANSWER.PARA: out of the labour ward into the visitors lounge—
There were no beds and no ward. At 6 pm, we went back again and the situation had not changed.

PARA.TAB: As there were five other mothers ahead of her, all without a ward or bed, her only option was to join them in the recovery room. Instead she rang her husband and arranged to go home.
There is something sadly wrong in this State—

ANSWER.PARA: that is, South Australia—
when new mothers can't be given a hospital bed, yet judges get repeated salary increases.
The letter writer went on to say:

PARA.TAB: There was one positive. The medical staff were absolutely wonderful, despite working under intolerable circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: That is the conservative government in South Australia cutting funds for the hospitals in that state. That is the sort of commitment to Medicare that we can expect from you, simultaneously privatising a large number of services.

PARA.TAB: In the ACT what do we see? A recently instituted conservative government is taking $20 million off the health budget and privatising community health services. That is the sort of commitment to Medicare that we are seeing from conservative governments around this country.

We have already seen what has happened in Victoria. They have cut their budget by 10 per cent or some $169 million, having put some of it back in. In Western Australia they have cut their budget by 17 per cent and in South Australia, by 12 per cent. Queensland has not cut back. That is the point. It has been adding significant funding.

I will give you an example—and I am sure the member for Dunkley will be very interested in this—of the Victorian government's method of budget cutting. There are nine people with intellectual disabilities in Victoria, the youngest of whom is 12, who are inappropriately housed in nursing homes. People as young as 12 with disabilities are being pushed by the Victorian government into nursing homes in the Westernport region.

Why? It is to save the Victorian government half a million dollars and to shift the cost to the Commonwealth, because we fund nursing homes. This is totally inappropriate for young people with intellectual disabilities. The Victorian minister claims that his department had referred just five of them, not nine, and the others had chosen to go there. How can he say chosen when he closed the other facilities, cut $32 million from accommodation services and promised a further three more? That is your commitment to Medicare.

—My question without notice is directed to the Treasurer and concerns bank fees. Can the Treasurer provide the House with any information flowing from his request to banks to advise on their progress in responding to the PSA inquiry into bank fees, and could he comment on the attitude of the opposition to this matter?
—The first part of the question is in order. The last part calls also for the expression of an opinion. The Treasurer will not respond.

—Last Friday I received a brief summary from the Prices Surveillance Authority of the progress the banks have made in responding to its recommendations on bank fees. The PSA will be undertaking some further analysis and continuing to have discussions with the banks. I cannot be specific to the House about what each institution has said, because the information was supplied in confidence. Of course, it is a competitive market and it is appropriate that it is supplied commercial-in-confidence.

PARA.TAB: What I can say from the information supplied to me is that it is clear that there is a move away from account keeping fees based on a minimum monthly balance. That is a very good thing because these fees impose most heavily on—in fact, they only apply to—people with small accounts, who are mostly low income earners. Ninety per cent of bank fees are accounted for by the account keeping fee. To remove that discrimination against people on low incomes is a very important development.
There also appears to be a move towards the provision of a number of free transactions per month regardless of the account balance. That, of course, is also a very good step.

There are already a number of products with appropriate features around. The Commonwealth Bank has already announced that it is extending the exemption on all account fees to age pensioners who are already customers of that bank. What the Commonwealth had previously done was to exempt from fees pensioners who were already pensioners as of December last year. They have now extended that to any future customers of the bank, to all existing pensioners and to all new pensioners who have been customers of the bank. All Commonwealth Bank customers who become pensioners in the future will be able to be freed of fees.

The National Australia Bank already has a passbook account which offers fee free banking for all DSS recipients except for the unemployed. I understand that the unemployed are exempted from that because of the movement in and out of employment and the problems that that would create in terms of accounting.

The Commonwealth Bank has also moved to provide free over-the-counter service to those people with disabilities that are reliant on over-the-counter access. This is a very good thing. It was announced by the Commonwealth Bank just a few days ago. I would certainly encourage other banks to follow this example in relation to the disabled, because these people are going to have great difficulty in accessing ATMs unless they are especially designed for them, and very few of the banks have done that to this stage. If they cannot use the ATMs, they have no alternative but to go to the counter. They should receive appropriate recognition for that and get the kind of treatment that the Commonwealth Bank is now intending to provide.

As I have said before, what the government wants to see is the removal of account keeping fees based on account balances, access to a reasonable number of free transactions per month—and by that I mean more than one a week—and with some of these fee free transactions to be over-the-counter services. On the timing of all this, I expect that the banks will announce these product changes before the end of this year for implementation no later than early next year. Some banks have already indicated that they intend to make these changes before the end of this year. I would also remind the banks that I do not expect these changes to be accompanied by any overall increase in the fees charged to individuals.

The Prices Surveillance Authority has also made recommendations on the treatment of inward cheque dishonours and fees on dormant accounts. The banks are generally moving towards the PSA recommendation on cheque dishonours, which was for abolition of the inward dishonoured cheque, but the reaction so far in relation to dormant accounts has been somewhat mixed. Some are moving in the right direction; others have not indicated that they are doing so.

Some of the banks do not appear to be responding to the PSA recommendations in a completely satisfactory manner, and I will be drawing these deficiencies to their attention. It is important to note that we are not expecting the banks to provide identical products. This is a competitive system. We can expect them to come up with different solutions to the problem that has been identified. They are generally moving in the right direction. Overall, we expect to have a good array of alternatives available for people to choose from and to provide a much more equitable system than we have had in the past.

If we do not get an appropriate response—I expect we will, but if it turns out not to be the case—then we do have the option of regulation. That would certainly not be our preference. I do not expect that we would have to use it but, if we have to, we will.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health: Legal Aid

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Attorney-General. Is the Attorney-General aware that in the 1994-95 financial year there were 5,500 unsuccessful applications for legal aid in Western Australia? Is he further aware that, of those 5,500 unsuccessful applications, more than 3,200 satisfied the tests under the current guidelines; that is, tests relating to income and assets, the merits of their cases and the type of case? Has your government agreed to fund the challenge by the Minister for Human Services and Health to the Marks royal commission to the tune of $10,000 a day? With the Minister for Human Services and Health's parliamentary income and allowances exceeding four times average weekly earnings, what message are you sending to those 3,200 Western Australian battlers who have been refused aid?

—I accept that the honourable member no doubt has a genuine concern about the funding for legal aid in the state of Western Australia; therefore, I will take his question in that spirit. As the House would be well aware, the Marks royal commission established by the Western Australian government is a responsibility of that government. The position of the Commonwealth has been that the costs which flow from that royal commission should be borne by the government which establishes it. That, of course, is the principle that the Commonwealth applies in terms of commissions of inquiry which it establishes and which state governments have also followed.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member mentioned the question of challenges to the commission, implying that a different set of rules somehow should apply. Obviously they did not apply to the New South Wales Liberal government of John Fahey, who funded former Premier Nick Greiner to challenge in the New South Wales Supreme Court the finding of the Independent Commission Against Corruption against Mr Greiner. Nor did it apply to the Groom government in Tasmania, which funded the challenge by former Liberal Premier Robin Gray to the proceedings of the Rouse royal commission in Tasmania. And that same rule should apply obviously to the Western Australian government. It is only upon the failure of the Western Australian government to meet its responsibilities that the Commonwealth government will become involved in the matter.

The honourable member mentioned the number of unsuccessful legal aid applications in Western Australia in the previous financial year. I note his concern about this. If he has a concern about the level of funding for legal aid in Western Australia, I ask the honourable member to note that the amount spent by the Western Australian government on its absolutely futile and never-having-any-chance-at-all challenge to the native title legislation, together with the cost to the Western Australian taxpayers of the Marks royal commission, will exceed in this year the amount which the Western Australian government commits to legal aid in that state.

The Commonwealth, for its part, recognises that legal aid requires additional funding. That is why in March of this year the Prime Minister announced as part of the Justice Statement a $24 million increase in legal aid. That money in proportion will flow to Western Australia. It will flow to the constituents he has mentioned. That money is earmarked to go to family law and civil law.

If you are really concerned about legal aid applicants in Western Australia missing out on funding, then direct to the government of Western Australia your concern about its futile use of taxpayers' money in challenging in the High Court the native title legislation and its setting up of the witch-hunt, the Marks royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Tourism. Bearing in mind the importance of the tourism industry to Queensland, can the minister advise the House on recently released Australian Bureau of Statistics tourist arrival figures, particularly those relating to Japanese tourists? What is the government doing to stimulate further growth in international tourism to Australia?

—I thank the member for Moreton for his question and continuing interest in the tourism industry, particularly the Queensland tourism industry. It is an industry that last year generated more than $12,000 million in export earnings for Australia. This industry has boosted in the last decade or more the number of international visitors coming to Australia from less than one million a year to 3.5 million in the 12 months to July this year. Last Friday the latest figures came through. I was extremely pleased that the Australian Bureau of Statistics found for July this year a 17 per cent increase in the number of international visitors coming to Australia compared with July last year. The figures that really gladdened my soul were the ones showing a massive rebound in the number of Japanese tourists coming to Australia in July this year. The figures show an 18 per cent increase in the number of Japanese coming to Australia in July this year compared with July last year.

PARA.TAB: The reason I am so pleased about this is that a few media reports, particularly in the Financial Review, have suggested that Japanese interest in holidaying in Australia was fading. No doubt both sides of the House were concerned about the impact that the Kobe earthquake might have had on Japanese travel, and there has been a bit of a shake in the economic confidence in Japan with the rise in the value of the yen. I am very pleased that we are seeing the new Kansai airport coming on line and the fact that Qantas and Ansett are now flying directly between Kansai and Australia reflected in the massive increases in the figures released last Friday. I have also been informed by my department that we can expect this dramatic improvement to continue, given that the visa approvals in Japan for holidays in Australia were up 25 per cent for July and up a further 12 per cent in August.

Not only are more people choosing to holiday in Australia but also all the statistics show that, when people come to Australia, they spend more money during their holiday. The figures show that even if you exclude the cost of the air fare the average tourist from another country holidaying in Australia spends $1,886 during their holiday.

I was intrigued to look at the hit parade concerning which visitors from which country spend the most and which spend the least. You might be surprised, Mr Speaker, to learn that it is the Indonesians these days—all 106,000 of them who came to Australia last year—who are the biggest spenders, spending $3,378 on average during their visits. The country whose visitors spent least per day was Britain. The British spent $43 each day. It would be wrong to conclude that the Poms have long pockets, because they tend to stay longer in Australia than people from other countries. They stay an average of 45 days. I understand that many of these English visitors are family and friends of the member for Fowler and that he is in part responsible for many of the English visitors.

Last week I launched the Australian Tourist Commission advertising campaign in Asia. This advertising campaign will see $100 million spent over the next three years in promoting Australia as a tourism destination. We will be running advertisements in Europe, America, Japan and Asia and we will be attracting more and more visitors to Australia through this campaign. I know that the member for Moreton would be interested to know that some of those advertisements will be run under the Partnership Australia campaign. I think most of the state and territory tourist commissions are involved. In particular, the QTTC will be working in partnership with the Australian Tourist Commission in attracting as many visitors as possible to some of the parts of Australia that the member for Moreton would like them to visit—perhaps the theme parks in south-east Queensland. I know that the member for Herbert would like them to be visiting Townsville and points north.

I will be launching the advertisements for the Australian tourism industry tomorrow and I am pleased to say, Mr Speaker, that with your cooperation and that of the President of the Senate these advertisements will be on show to the general public in the Parliament House theatrette from tomorrow. I invite any honourable members who are interested in seeing how we promote Australia in other countries to visit the theatrette and see the clear determination and commitment of this government in generating more jobs and export earnings through the growing Australian tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the quarter of an hour that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) had to explain his continued assertion, and that of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), that there is a direct link between foreign debt and the interest rates that people of Australia are paying on their mortgages, he did not explain how that link works. He cannot explain it. He simply made that allegation. The Leader of the Opposition made that allegation when launching his lorry of lies out the front. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If it weren't for the level of foreign debt, interest rates in this country would be much lower, and every Australian today who owes money on his or her home is paying a higher interest rate than would otherwise be the case because of the size of our foreign debt.

When he said that, he had no justification for saying it. He still has no justification for saying it. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition made a speech for a quarter of an hour and there was not one word of explanation. There was not a word to explain how it all works. He was just saying, `This is my allegation and there are a couple of people that I can mention who think I might be right.'

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the person in charge of monetary policy in this country says that you are not right, so start off with that point. The person who is actually in charge of monetary policy, the Governor of the Reserve Bank, says that the debt is a minor issue at best in terms of domestic interest rates in this country and that the issues being pursued by the opposition are totally out of the field. It is just not true to say that there is any sensible link between foreign debt and mortgage interest rates. That proposition, if it is going to be alleged, ought to be justified.

Let me make the point again: the fact is that mortgage interest rates are set on the basis of the short-term official interest rates. They are a margin above that. The short-term official interest rates are set not by market but by the Reserve Bank in conjunction with the government. The Reserve Bank has made—certainly whilst I have been Treasurer—the initiative for any particular change of monetary policy. We accepted what they proposed in relation to the three increases last year.

Those three increases had nothing whatever to do with foreign debt. There was not one skerrick of a mention of foreign debt. It was due to the fact that we were moving interest rates up because we believed it was important for us to take the step to put a stitch in time against inflation as the economy, having had a relatively long period of growth, was likely to develop some inflationary forces unless some action was taken with monetary policy, which had been eased enormously since the late 1980s. Again, those easings had nothing to do with foreign debt. In looking at those monetary policy settings last year, the action taken to increase interest rates was because of the need to take some anti-inflationary action. It was not anything to do with foreign debt.

The margins that are set for mortgage rates are based on the official rate which has been determined by official action which is in turn aimed at inflation or at macro-economic outcomes. The reductions which occurred—the whole stream of them from the late 1980s—were about trying to get the economy back onto a growth path. The increases were about trying to restrain inflation. None of them had anything to do, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank said, with the level of foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.

—He said that none of those increases had anything to do with foreign debt. He said that none of those reductions had anything to do with foreign debt. It is quite clear that the setting of short-term interest rates in this country is determined not on the basis of foreign debt but on the basis of macro-economic stability. The mortgage rates that feed off them are therefore related to those factors and are not related to foreign debt.

PARA.TAB: That is not to say that foreign debt has no impact at all on any interest rate. As I said at question time—and I said it last Thursday—if the government is going to borrow overseas, then clearly, if it has a lower rating than it might have had previously, there is a higher premium to pay in terms of the interest rate that will be required to make the appropriate borrowings. I have made that point. That is quite clear.

From that there are two points. Firstly, how big is that premium? I said something about that at question time today. The second point is: how does that translate into a mortgage rate which is being set on the basis of official interest rates—which are not being determined on the basis of foreign debt but are being set on the basis of macro-economic stability? That is the process. What is this link? The member for Higgins had a quarter of an hour to make his speech and show a link, and he had no idea what the link was. He had no idea.

The fact is that, as I demonstrated at question time, if the opposition want to say that there is some kind of a link then it is absolutely incumbent upon them to demonstrate that there is a link. If they are going to say to the Australian people, `You are paying more in interest rates because of foreign debt,' they should be able to prove that charge. They simply cannot show how it works. They cannot show how it works because it does not work.

There is also the issue, as I said, of the size of any premium that we would pay. The size of that premium, as referred to by Dr FitzGerald in his report on savings, was about 0.5 per cent. As I said at question time, the Treasury has done further work on that and reckons, from its calculations, that the premium is now more like 0.09 per cent, less than 0.1 per cent. That is what they see as the difference in terms of borrowings in overseas markets at AA instead of AAA. That is the relevance of foreign debt in terms of the rating and therefore the additional premium we have to pay because of a lower rating. It is a minuscule amount on government borrowing.

Then, according to the opposition, this flows back into the Australian economy in some way they have not explained, reflects itself in mortgage interest rates and leads to the outcome which the Leader of the Opposition says means that people are paying much higher interest rates than would otherwise be the case. How can he possibly justify a claim of that kind when the premium is so small and he cannot even show how it flows back into the domestic economy, let alone into interest rates for mortgages, which is where he made his claim?

It is absurd for the opposition to be going around with their truck trying to demonstrate to the Australian people that there is a link when they cannot possibly show that there is a link and when the premium that we pay because of a lower rating because of foreign debt is so small and you cannot see how it comes back onto mortgage interest rates.

I noted that last Friday a couple of economists in the market commented on this. For instance, the Bankers Trust's senior economist, Rory Robertson, said that the level of foreign debt had close enough to no influence on variable housing rates. The National Australia Bank chief economist, Mr Allan Oster, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is easier to argue Mr Willis's case than the coalition's, but there are a couple of issues which made Mr Willis only about 80 per cent right. If Australia's high foreign debt put downward pressure on the Australian dollar, the threat of higher inflation could force the Reserve Bank to lift interest rates, leading banks to raise their variable mortgage rates.

We have not faced that situation. We have had variations in the dollar—that is for sure—but we have not been adjusting interest rates to offset that inflationary factor, so you cannot point to that kind of flow through as a factor in pushing up interest rates in this country.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that if you look at other countries, at the level of foreign debt and the level of short-term interest rates, you simply cannot see any relation. As I said at question time, there is no demonstrable relationship that you can show. Of those countries that had lower foreign debt than we do, only two had lower short-term interest rates—only two. Where is the relationship between foreign debt and short-term interest rates, from which the mortgage rates are set, if it is as the opposition says—that there is such a relationship? You cannot see it, looking at other countries.

It is just another example of the determination of this opposition—this policy free opposition, this opposition which simply has no policies—to say nothing to the Australian people about what it stands for. It simply wants to bag the government all the time—bag a government which is doing much better than most other Western countries in terms of the fundamentals that matter to the Australian people. The government is doing much better in terms of building up the level of growth in this country, producing growth at the top levels of countries in the Western developed world, producing employment growth at the top levels of Western industrialised countries—and doing it in the context of low inflation.

These are terrific outcomes. These are the sorts of outcomes that John Howard would have given his right arm for when he was Treasurer of this country, because he could not produce anything like that. He had growth of one per cent per annum less than we have had. He had employment growth of only one-third of the rate that we have had. He had inflation which on average was much higher than—almost double—what we have had. He left this country with double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and the worst recession for 50 years at that stage—now, going on from there, for 60 years. The worst recession, the deepest recession, we have had since the 1930s occurred when John Howard, the now Leader of the Opposition, was Treasurer. That is the kind of comparison that we can make with the previous government.

This government has much to be proud of for what it has been able to achieve in terms of growth, employment, improvement of real incomes and low inflation. These are terrific outcomes compared with the standards of effort by the previous government. Of course, that has all been accompanied by a massive structural change to the Australian economy in a way which is very beneficial for our future prospects.

Certainly it has been accompanied by an increase in foreign debt. We do not deny that. There has been an increase in foreign debt. But it is part of the internationalisation of the Australian economy and the fact that Australian businesses have borrowed, as the budget papers say, in substantial part, to invest overseas. Australian investment overseas by companies has gone up from 10 per cent of GDP to virtually 30 per cent of GDP, a point made in the budget papers. It has been facilitated by foreign borrowing by those companies.

This is not a bad thing for the Australian people if the borrowings are offset by assets, and there are substantial assets against them. Whether they are here or overseas does not matter much as long as they are productive assets and produce an income stream which comes back to Australia.

Looking just at the debt and not at the assets is absurd. You have to look at the whole scene. The opposition line that there is $10,000 of debt for every Australian person is a scaremongering tactic. You have to look at all the assets that sit against that. The World Bank says that we have got $1 million of assets per person in Australia. You can put your $10,000 against the $1 million of assets for each Australian. That perhaps gets it in some kind of better perspective.
Finally, in relation to the allegation that the budget papers support the opposition, the budget papers do no such thing. The Budget Statements say at page 2-36:

SPEECH.PARA: However, a high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premia on borrowings.

In relation to borrowings overseas, that is clear. I have already said that. That is what happens. But the premium is very small. We do not have to say that that represents an increase in mortgage interest rates because of higher foreign debt. It simply does not follow. The budget papers do not say that, and there is just no reason to believe that there is any support for the opposition's case in what is in the budget papers. The budget papers make it clear that the increase in foreign debt has assets against it, and that is a very important matter for the Australian people to bear in mind.

PARA.TAB: Finally, our level of foreign debt is certainly not the highest in the Western industrialised world. Two very comparable countries—New Zealand and Canada—have higher foreign debt as a proportion of GDP than we do. To simply say that the Australian people are bearing a higher interest rate because of foreign debt is a total non sequitur when you notice that the level of interest rates in general in New Zealand has been less than ours, despite the fact that their foreign debt has been much higher. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this matter of public importance to again go through what has been a trumped up process run by the opposition on the issue of debt. Last week, the opposition launched the lorry of lies—what is now a broken down truck—which contained a load of garbage in terms of the assertions made by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: The claim being made at that stage was that for every Australian man, woman and child there is a $10,000 debt. Bills purporting to represent that debt have been sent out in many electorates. When the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was challenged about this last week when the truck was outside Parliament House, he said, `No, I do not really mean that. That is not quite what I mean. I am suggesting that there is a link between the levels of foreign debt and mortgage interest rates.' Since then there has been a lot of discussion. The opposition is gradually moving away from that and is attempting to say something different. If we wait long enough, no doubt it will be able to come up with a consistent approach to these issues.

I will deal with the question of mortgage interest rates first. The government has established through its discussions—both in the lead-up to the budget and in matters since then, when we have talked about the current account and debt—the need to develop short- and medium-term strategies to meet our current account problem and, in turn, to take appropriate strategies to deal with the debt issue.

We have put the issue into proper context rather than engage and indulge in a scare campaign which the opposition hopes might substitute for a policy, but it will not. Today the debt servicing ratio that the country has to meet is 11 per cent. In 1983 it was nine per cent. It has turned around in the last few years as the economy has changed. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank said yesterday, there have been 15 movements in official rates over the last four to five years. On none of those occasions was the claim made that there was a link between mortgage interest rates and foreign debt.

Obviously, the movements in official interest rates involved the broader monetary policy consideration and the overall management of the economy and were to kick-start the economy out of the recession and to ensure that we had a sustainable level of growth. The 16th quarter of growth has ticked over in Australia. The opposition keeps trying to run this charge about foreign debt when the economy is achieving world standards in growth—16 quarters of growth. There is every prospect that that will continue in a sustained way. The government is achieving something that the opposition never could when it had custody of the Treasury: no boom-bust cycle that Australian economies have historically gone through.

The government will achieve that. That has been made clear by the 16 quarters of growth and the fact that our short-term interest rates are very competitive internationally. People make league table claims about who is better than whom on all these issues. It is quite appropriate to point out that, as far as a link between foreign debt and short-term interest rates is concerned, we are in a very competitive position. We are amongst the best of all the OECD countries in terms of short-term interest rates. Even if it were possible to establish this axiomatic linkage between mortgage interest rates and debt—and the charge has not been sustained anyway—it has been shown that government strategies have, in the management of short-term interest rates, achieved that objective.

To have a sensible discussion about these issues we need to go back a step or two and look at the current account, the statement the Treasurer (Mr Willis) released on the medium-term budget strategy earlier this year, the action that was taken in the budget and the savings strategy the government has put in place. People have quoted Vince FitzGerald and others on this issue but no-one has disputed the strategies the government has established in order to achieve a budget surplus this year—the first budget surplus since the recession and only the fourth budget surplus in 30 years; all achieved by Labor governments—a stronger budget structural surplus next year and a comprehensive strategy to increase the level of national savings. These are the things that ensure that we deal with the current account problem.

The budget forecast this year makes clear that our current account position will improve through 1995-96. The Treasurer made clear last Thursday in question time that he thinks we will do better than the budget time forecast because the economy has achieved both the soft landing and sustainable level of growth that we saw as critical at the time of the budget.

In addition to that, we outlined a major enhancement of the national savings strategy through superannuation. That has been a feature of this government. Bear in mind that, when we came into government, 40 per cent of people had superannuation. In the last quarter, we had superannuation investment assets of $198 billion. That figure was released by the Statistician last Thursday. How has that been achieved? It has been achieved through the superannuation guarantee, the savings strategy the government established over the last few years. That superannuation savings strategy is already providing a contribution of a half per cent of GDP and over the next few years it will rise to two per cent of GDP. That is how substantial the budget superannuation initiatives are.

When we have discussions about the current account, we indicate that the magnitude of percentage of GDP which we need to satisfy our current account, and, therefore, to take the further steps to stabilise our foreign debt position, is a quota of about 1 1/2 per cent of GDP. The superannuation savings strategy will add two per cent of GDP per annum. So let us not kid ourselves that there is not a strategy to deal with this issue. The Australian community should be reassured that the government has a firm strategy to meet the current account problem.

We come to the issue of what this foreign debt represents. We have not had any sensible discussion about what the debt represents from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) or the member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) who have contributed to this MPI. Investment in this country has grown dramatically in the last couple of years. It has grown to proportions that the opposition said at budget time in 1994 and 1995 were unsustainable. When we forecast the figure of 14 1/2 per cent in 1994, the opposition said that it would never be achieved. In fact, we have achieved 25 per cent. In relation to this year's forecast, we had claims from the opposition that the economy was going into a double-dip recession. That was as recently as three or four months ago. What a nonsense that looks like today. It is the same nonsense we are now getting about foreign debt.

Companies have been borrowing from overseas to finance business investment. Much of the investment has been in Australia, but not all of it. Why is that? It is partly because we have tried to globalise the economy. If a major bank or another institution in Australia thinks there is value in having at least part of their investment strategy in offshore arrangements, that is something that reflects well on the overall maturity and the depth of our economy. What does investment here and abroad mean? It means more economic activity, more jobs and a more sustainable livelihood for all Australians. That is what we should be concerned about, because that is what, in part, this private sector debt—over 60 per cent of the foreign debt—is all about.

The key point to make about any level of debt is the capacity to service it. What we are getting in the 1990s, unlike the situation of the past, is companies making sustained long-term capital investment, reinvesting to provide those long-term opportunities in Australia, and at the same time ensuring that the nation gains a significant improvement in national wealth as a result of it. We should not be saying that all foreign debt is bad or that the government does not have the strategy to effectively manage the servicing of it.

Both the government and the private sector are ensuring that that happens. We are ensuring that there is a sustainable level of economic growth, and we are particularly building upon the strong achievements of our superannuation savings strategy to ensure that we meet the current account challenge and achieve what we have not been able to achieve before—sustainable levels of national savings, sustainable levels of growth, sustainable levels of improvement in employment—and doing it on a low inflation base.

These are things that the opposition could not achieve when it was in government. Rather than coming in with this sort of knocking scare campaign aimed at the Australian people for cheap electoral purposes, the opposition, if they do not agree with this strategy, should be saying what their alternative is to deal with this issue rather than running around the country with this lorry of lies, the garbage truck which offers nothing in public policy terms.
