The member for Bennelong has been going around Sydney telling everyone that reopening the east-west runway will solve all their problems but he does not tell them how that will occur. Of course, he has no idea how that will occur. The member for Bennelong has not worked out that the east-west runway was never closed. It still operates in adverse conditions when there are crosswinds or congestion restricting the use of the north-south runways. He says, `Reopen it,' as if that is all there is to it. In his view we should not worry about the extensive and expensive environmental impact study that was carried out in relation to the construction of the parallel runway in Sydney. According to the Leader of the Opposition we should forget about the process and just reopen the east-west runway.

The Attorney-General's Department has given evidence that it is clear that a full environmental impact study would be required for any proposal to use the east-west runway for jet operations. The Leader of the Opposition does not tell people that the reason why the east-west runway was downgraded was that that was part of the lawful approval for the parallel runway—the runway that he and his party are so very keen should be implemented.

The Leader of the Opposition does not tell people whether he will make provision for an installation and acquisition program for those severely affected by noise in Sydney's inner west. This is the program that was initiated by this government. Will the Leader of the Opposition make provision to extend that to the 58,000 people who will be affected by the reopening of the east-west runway? Of course he won't!

In 1989, and recently at the Senate committee hearings, the member for Bennelong said that the impact of aircraft noise on these people in the south of Sydney is grossly exaggerated. He said that the great bulk of them are only mildly affected and, in any event, they bought their houses knowing full well that they would be under the flight path. The Leader of the Opposition made these remarks in that infamous interview with Mike Carlton. The Leader of the House read more fully from that interview today.

In that interview the Leader of the Opposition had the hide to say that he knew a little bit about the politics of the St George district. For a fellow who reckons that he knows a little bit about the politics of the St George district he has scant regard for the people that he allegedly grew up with. All this fellow wants to do is dump aircraft noise back on those people. Why does he want to do that? He wants to do that because the good, honest burghers of Hunters Hill, Wollstonecraft and Woolwich have had their properties devalued.

We should forget about good old John Howard, the friend of the battler, the man who grew up in Canterbury and Earlwood and who knows all about the working people of this country. What would his gift be to those people if he, unfortunately, became Prime Minister of Australia or if, through some bizarre act, he got this legislation up? The Leader of the Opposition would revisit those people with aircraft noise. I would not like this bloke to know too much of the politics of my electorate because, if that is what he thinks knowing the politics of an area is all about, it shows a very dishonest approach to dealing with people.

He suggests that people bought their houses in these areas just recently. Those people have been affected by aircraft noise for decades. There is a lot faster turnover of housing on the old Hunters Hill peninsula than there is at Bexley and other parts of the St George region. The member for Bennelong, who used to live in Earlwood, has moved a long way away from those people—and it is not just from one side of the harbour to the other. His gift to those people, if he had his way, would be to dump aircraft noise in their backyards. He does not give a damn about those people because they are not in his electorate.

As has been mentioned by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) earlier in the debate, the member for Bennelong is a very recent convert to the cause of those affected by aircraft noise. The member for Lowe, the member for Grayndler (Ms McHugh), the member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin), the member for Barton (Mr Punch), the member for Kingsford-Smith and I have all been active in this campaign for years. The member for Bennelong was active in it, but he was active on the other side. His view was, `Open the third runway. Let it rip.'

The reason why the member for Bennelong has suddenly become converted to the idea that aircraft noise is a terrible thing is that his own constituents have finally got it through his thick head that they do not like this idea. I remember going to demonstrations in the early 1990s about Sydney airport and having people from Hunters Hill say to me that they thought that the actions of the member for Bennelong were disgraceful; that he could not give a damn about them; that he did not represent them; that he did not look after them; and that he did not do anything for them because he was in the bag with the New South Wales Liberal government which just wanted to let this airport rip and let it rip and let it rip.

Now that an election is coming close, the honourable member sees a bit of political advantage and all of a sudden becomes committed to the idea of political cynicism. No doubt the member for Warringah, who got up and asked him the little clever question today, is the one who has been saying to him, `Don't worry about any of this truth business. Get out there and be as cynical and dishonest as you possibly can be. There'll be a few votes in it somewhere. Tell `em anything.' That has always been the view of the member for Warringah. He will say anything and do anything as long as he wins. That is his attitude.

Of course the Leader of the Opposition has bought that and today the Leader of the House exposed him for the hypocrite he is. His view in 1989 and his view since then has been there is no real problem about aircraft noise—so he says. The people of my electorate, he used to say, are exaggerating all this. But now, all of a sudden, with an election in the wind the member for Warringah has told him to sniff the wind, and off they go, converts to the problems of the people of the inner west and the south-west of Sydney.

Even then he was not going to be honest in what he was doing. Had he put forward a private member's bill which said in the bill what he says is an amendment here, which is to increase the use of the runway known as the east-west runway, it might have been a bit more honest. But instead he cloaked it in a bill that was supposed to be doing something about the curfew. The reality is that he cares nought for the curfew. What he wants to do is inflict pain on the people he grew up with. He wanted to sneak this little bill into the House and try to get his amendment to re-open the east-west runway through without notice. But the problem is that we have noticed it. The Morris committee has also noticed it. We are not going to let him or the opposition get away with compromising safety, decreasing capacity at the airport and throwing the noise onto more and more people.

The member for Bennelong disregarded the EIS process for reopening the east-west runway. His disregard for that process is indicative of his attitude to aircraft operations and safety. Despite the experts' statements that concurrent operation of intersecting runways is not as safe as parallel runways, the member for Bennelong steams ahead and says, `We must have intersecting runways. That's the only way that those fine Liberal voters in Woolwich and Hunters Hill will keep voting for me. Therefore we have to do something to hurt the people in south-western Sydney.' The opposition have all sorts of tricky policies that they try to keep close to their chest. Every time we see a little more of what they are up to it is exposed for the attack on ordinary working people that it is.

The Leader of the Opposition is going to bat for the people of Hunters Hill and Woolwich. He might try to clothe it and say that he is looking after the interests of the electorate of the member for Lowe and the electorate of the member for Grayndler, but he has scant or no regard for them. He is looking after the property values of Hunters Hill and Woolwich. Who are the people he is attacking? The people of Bexley, Kingsgrove and Beverly Hills. If you ever wanted a metaphor for what the opposition's policies are about across a whole range of things, this unseemly little bill that he was putting forward here is a good one. It is about entrenching privilege on the North Shore of Sydney and attacking the working people of south-western Sydney; keeping up property values at Hunters Hill and Woolwich and attacking the people of Bexley, Beverly Hills and Kingsgrove—attacking them without even giving them the chance of having an environmental impact statement look at what should happen.

This is one of the best examples of nimby policies I have seen for a long while. The myth the member for Bennelong is perpetrating in his electorate is that somehow or other all the noise in Hunters Hill and Woolwich will go away and those other poor people on the other side of the harbour can catch it all. That is his view and it is a dishonest view. It is not the truth and they know it.

The member for Bennelong has stated publicly on a number of occasions that he thinks this is the only answer. I have a pile of papers showing occasions and how short-sighted, inequitable and how patently unsafe that course of action is. Despite that the member for Bennelong persists. He chooses to forget once again that it was his party, the Liberal Party in New South Wales, from which he sprang and which John Fahey was a Premier of—they were the ones who were hand in hand with the developers—that wanted the third runway in the first place. He pushed for the third runway, along with his cronies in the New South Wales government at the time. Now he has the gall to whinge that planes are using it and causing his constituents some trouble.

Does the member now intend that we return to the simultaneous operations of the east-west and north-south runways and close the third runway? Is that one of the solutions he wants to propose? It was part of the EIS provisions for the opening of the parallel runway that operations on the east-west would be scaled back, so it would be used when weather conditions on the north-south runway precluded that runway from being used. The member for Bennelong knew that the use of the east-west runway would be reduced once the third runway was operational. It did not worry him much at the time but, as I said earlier, self-interest has come creeping into this.

Let us look at what would happen if we did reopen the east-west runway, as the honourable member for Bennelong has suggested. He says he is not an expert in the area, yet he continues to reject the advice of experts concerning safety. He says that he has seen no evidence that simultaneous operations on the east-west and intercepting parallel runways would be unsafe. Because he has not seen it, it does not exist. Perhaps if he removed his hands from his eyes he would be able to see. Instead he is telling the 58,000 people in the south-west of Sydney that they should put their hands over their ears so they do not hear the noise he wants to inflict upon them.

The Civil Aviation Authority, which is now Airservices Australia, has repeatedly stated that it strongly advised against the use of the east-west runway in intercepting operations with the parallel runway system. Concerns have also been raised by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, international experts and airline pilots. Of course, we have seen the horrific pictures that the minister provided of scenarios at Sydney airport that could have seen collisions using the east-west runway simultaneously with the north-south runway.

Just recently, both Qantas and Ansett stated publicly that they believed parallel operations were far safer than intercepting operations. It just seems that the Leader of the Opposition is out of step with everybody else. Use of the east-west runway by jets would reduce capacity at the airport. Parallel runway operations enable an average of 80 movements per hour while the average attained by using cross-runways is about 57 movements per hour.

The member for Bennelong insists that we had to have the third runway to increase the capacity. Does he say that does not matter any more? This is the area where the member demonstrates his absolute ignorance of the issue. He says he wants to reduce jet noise over his electorate and other suburbs to the north of the airport. However, reopening the east-west runway will allow the airlines to land propeller-driven aircraft on the stub of the east-west and will allow at least 10 more jets an hour on the north-south runway. Is this not a rather masochistic way of sharing the pain? The outcome will be only more pain for people to the north and south of the runway and more pain all around. The irony would be laughable if it were not such a serious matter for the people of Sydney.

We have to thank the member for Bennelong for his amendment, his sad little amendment, which has given us the opportunity of seeing the inadequacy of his and his party's grasp of the complex issues relating to Sydney airport. The member has shown once again that his side are not concerned in the slightest with long-term planning needs. The best he could come up with was a bill that underlined the provisions the government has already put in place for curfews at Sydney. There is nothing new in what he says. The best he could do was grab his pen and say, `A tick for the government'—because that is what his bill says: `A tick for the government'.

The Sydney airport saga is a long-running one and I think we all know—with the exception of the member for Bennelong and the member for Warringah who puts him up to these stunts—that there are no quick fixes to the issue. The government is committed to the only real solution, which is a second airport for Sydney at Sydney West. The government's proposals will have that airport up and running in time for the Olympics and, thanks to the government, we will then get some advantages in noise reduction at Sydney airport. But, of course, none of that is any thanks to the opposition—no thanks whatsoever.

The bill that the government has put forward not only builds on the curfew provisions that are already there, but also reduces the number of international passenger aircraft during the first and last hours of the curfew. It aims to stop aircraft departing right on 11 p.m. and guidelines for assessing applications for curfew dispensations will be prepared with public consultation. The minister will be required to table reasons for each dispensation in parliament within five days. Penalties have been substantially increased up to $100,000 for corporations.
The bill the government is bringing forward today is a positive one. I congratulate the minister, I congratulate Mr Morris and his committee and I commend the bill to the House.

The opposition should really think twice about these tawdry, politically poll-driven attempts to distort the truth for the people of Sydney and they should admit, as was exposed by the Leader of the House today, that the Leader of the Opposition and his quests for the member for Warringah are shams and frauds. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely delighted to follow in this debate the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), whose previous contributions to transport policy were: falling off his bike on Lake Burley Griffin at enormous expense to the taxpayer; deliberately pranging the Labor Party's car in the basement of Sussex Street, as revealed by Fia Cumming in her book Mates; and having what he described as a `very satisfactory' little accident when he fell off his motor scooter when working for Telstra.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that the member for Watson kept talking about `my electorate'. In 1989, the time he kept referring to, his electorate was different from the electorate he now represents. Why? Because this man, the member for Watson, was such a brilliant member for Grayndler that his own preselectors did not want him and they put in someone else, the current Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh). So I suggest that, really, the member for Watson should stick to flying in aircraft rather than trying to analyse aircraft and airport policy.

Today, the government is desperately, desperately, desperately playing catch-up politics. There is one reason and one reason only for this Sydney Airport Curfew Bill now before the House and that is the private member's bill of the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), which is the first attempt in 12 1/2 years to try to entrench the curfew that this government now claims to be so concerned about.

Do you know why, Mr Deputy Speaker, we are now debating this? Because the Prime Minister, the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), believes that no-one else in the big, wide, wonderful world can ever have a good idea except him. When the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, came up with a perfectly reasonable, perfectly acceptable bill, what did the Prime Minister say? He said, `We can't have this because we can't have the member for Bennelong doing anything at all.' He certainly cannot have the member for Bennelong showing him up by doing something that should have been done 12 1/2 years ago. That is the problem—the Prime Minister is `Paul Perfect' and nothing is allowed to detract from his perfection, not even cameras in this parliament shooting him from behind and exposing his bald spot.

We had the Prime Minister the other day talking about his former colleague, and indeed friend, Vince FitzGerald. What did he say? He spoke about lemon juice and sucking on lemons. Quite frankly, all I can say is that the Prime Minister must be spending too much time looking in the mirror lately, because the only one producing citric acid in the quantities that the Prime Minister refers to is the Prime Minister himself, and the Prime Minister is detecting his own vices in others.

The basic problem is that this third runway that the government has given us is not a third runway at all. It is a replacement second runway. There are not three functioning runways at Sydney airport. There are now simply two functioning runways at Sydney airport. All the problems that the so-called third runway were supposed to address are in fact worse today, thanks to the so-called third runway that this government has brought in.

The so-called third runway was supposed to mean less noise and more flights. It has actually meant more noise and fewer flights. The so-called third runway was supposed to mean that more aircraft would be taking off and landing over Botany Bay. That means there was supposed to be less noise for everyone. That is what the government kept telling us about this so-called third runway and that is why so many people on that side of the House and this side of the House supported it. Because we believed this government, foolishly, when it said that the so-called third runway was going to mean less noise and more flights.

But, in fact, the so-called third runway has meant that Sydney airport has become a byword for chaos. Sydney airport has become legendary, not so much in its own lunchtime or its own dreamtime, but in the extra time the flights are up in the air because of the chaos that this government has produced.

Do you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in the 24 hours after this so-called third runway was brought into operation Ansett Australia had 30,000 phone calls of complaint? You have to ask yourself: why is this so? Why has the so-called third runway turned out to be a $200 million failure? As the Leader of the Opposition pointed out in his excellent answer to a splendidly crafted question in the House today, the reason for this is because the Prime Minister interfered in the 1989 process.

The reason we have more noise and fewer flights is not because of the concept of the third runway but because the Prime Minister interfered. As Laurie Oakes and Graham Richardson revealed, and as the Leader of the Opposition reminded us today, the Prime Minister is personally to blame for the chaos at Sydney airport, the noise that hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders now face and the anguish and the pain that so many Sydneysiders now have to endure.

The Prime Minister has long had delusions of grandeur. Like Napoleon, like that other emperor that he so much admires, he has long wanted to be a great urban planner. He has long wanted to leave behind the city of his dreams. He wanted to pull down the Cahill Expressway. We all know that nothing has happened there. He wanted to turn the Finger Wharf into something beautiful, something Parisian. Nothing has happened there. The only mark that this Prime Minister has left on the city of Sydney is the third runway. The only thing that this Prime Minister has done, the only difference that this Prime Minister has made to urban planning in the city of Sydney is extra noise and extra chaos.

The Prime Minister's desire to emulate Napoleon has as much relationship to his practice as his paramount chief's headgear has to Napoleon's crown. The fact is that this government has not addressed any of the major problems of Sydney airport. You cannot even fly in but, if you could, you could not get out because of the pathetic infrastructure that currently `serves' Sydney airport. There are no decent roads to the south. There are no decent roads to the city itself. There is a maze of traffic lights.

There are certainly no roads to the west, to the electorate of the member for Watson. The member for Watson, this great champion of the people of inner western Sydney—what has the Prime Minister done to alleviate the burdens faced by his electors? Nothing! Not only do they have aircraft noise; they also have traffic noise because of the atrocious state of the roads in the member's electorate.

The only government of recent times which has done anything at all for the people of the inner west, has done anything at all to improve the state of Sydney airport, has been the previous Fahey government in New South Wales, which finally did what should have been done many years ago and began the construction of a rail link between the airport and the city.

The worst thing about this bill is that it reveals the hypocrisy and deceit of this government. When the government first opened the third runway and hundreds of thousands of Sydneysiders were inflicted with unbearable noise, the Leader of the Labor Party in New South Wales, Mr Carr, was running around saying, `Don't blame me. I am not like Paul Keating or Laurie Brereton.' Then when Mr Carr, in defiance of his election promises, left the tolls on the M4 and M5, we had Mr Keating going around the place saying, `Don't blame me—

Members opposite are trying to say that it is the Liberal Party which is responsible for the third runway. It was not John Howard, John Hewson, Alexander Downer or Andrew Peacock who stood there with the Minister for Transport on the tarmac the day it was opened; it was the Prime Minister. Yet they are trying to tell us that it is really the Liberal Party's fault, just as they are trying to tell us that tariff cuts are the Liberal Party's fault and spending cuts are the Liberal Party's fault. We heard the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) today trying to tell us that it was the fault of the South Australian government, in some way, that Labor's health policies are a failure. Foreign debt is supposed to be the fault of Bob Menzies.

The fact is that every time something goes wrong for this government it is someone else's fault. When it suits the Prime Minister, he says he has the Governor of the Reserve Bank, the Treasury, the press and the international financial markets in his pocket; but as soon as something goes wrong, `Oh no. It is not my fault; it is someone else's fault.' The people of Sydney and the people of Australia know whose fault it is and they know who is to blame. The responsible party—the guilty party—is, in fact, the Australian Labor Party.

The position of the opposition is quite clear. We believe that the third runway should be reopened. We believe that there should be burden sharing. We believe, if you like, in the transport equivalent of progressive taxation. We believe that if there is something unpleasant, something unfortunate, it should not all be dumped on one small group of people. We believe in a fair go for all the citizens of Sydney; not just those who happen to live in the electorates of the member for Watson, the member for Kingsford-Smith or the member for Blaxland. We believe in that light on the hill that they used to believe in, until the member for Blaxland extinguished it. We believe that governments should not put burdens unnecessarily on people's backs.

There are some burdens that government cannot remove—and should not even try to remove—but the fact of the matter is that government should never make people's burdens more heavy. This government has made the lives of hundreds of thousands of Australians that much less bearable than they were before, because of its policy with respect to Sydney airport. We believe that governments should not play favourites, that governments should not uniquely favour the electorates of the Prime Minister, the member for Kingsford-Smith and Minister for Transport, and the chief bovver boy, the member for Watson. Governments should treat every Australian equally and that is what the opposition's amendment will do with respect to the very serious problem of aircraft noise.

I will repeat the fundamental difference between the position of the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong, and the position of the government. When the member for Bennelong said what the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) quoted today, he said it on the basis of repeated assurances from this government that the opening of a third runway would mean less noise and more flights, and take-offs and landings over Botany Bay.

This statement, that the Leader of the House tried so very unsuccessfully to deride, was based on untruthful assurances from this government. The fact is that if that third runway means, as it has meant, more noise and fewer flights, if the third runway has completely contradicted everything that this government said it would mean, then it is perfectly right to go back to the system that existed before its opening and to reopen the east-west runway, as the member for Bennelong desires and as his bill provides.

The fact is that so many people have been betrayed by this government—people who thought they could trust the Labor Party. The problem with this government is that the longer it lasts the worse things get. The economy is worse. Interest rates are high and unreliable. Foreign debt is worse. Living standards are worse. Yet, the worse things get, the more loudly and the more hysterically this government boasts. We had a prime example of that today with the performance of not only the Leader of the House but also the Minister for Transport and, more recently, the member for Watson.

The Labor Party has tragically let down so many of its traditional supporters in inner western Sydney. It is all very well for the Minister for Transport to let these people down because he has a bolthole. He can always go to his million-dollar beach house on Palm Beach. The Prime Minister can let them down because, after all, he can always go to his $2.2 million mansion in Woollahra. It is interesting that the members opposite go to ALP areas when they are looking for safe seats but they come to Liberal areas when they are looking for nice houses. The fact is that on this issue the member for Bennelong speaks for Sydney. What Sydney is saying is that we are not going to be taken for granted any more by the Labor Party. TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to be able to speak to the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995 because it gives me the opportunity to place before the House a significant aspect of the bill that would probably not be touched upon otherwise. I notice that the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) is leaving the House. When he knows nothing about a bill, he usually plays the man and never plays the debate. That is typical of what we have come to expect from him.

PARA.TAB: Given the importance of strengthening the curfew at Sydney airport, it is understandable why the majority of speakers on the bill would address their comments to what seem to be the immediate issues. However, I have to question why the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) did not use her remaining 10 minutes of the debate. From my point of view, it is essential that I bring before this House an issue related to the bill which is equally important and which I believe in the long term could affect more people than the present bill's curfew once passed into legislation.

It is not that I object to the strengthening in this bill of the curfew at Sydney airport; I do not at all. I object to the bill's various clauses because there is an inherent understanding—I would not like to think the smell of a foregone conclusion—that the proposed airport at Badgerys Creek will be a no curfew operation, something which I have always fought against. This bill—which takes a much stronger stance on noise than the cynical and gutless vote catching private member's bill of the Leader of the Opposition—could in the end be just as divisive as it is conciliatory. I am determined to go down on record in this House as not objecting to the bill's provisions for what it means to those around Sydney airport. I think in that respect it will do a great deal for them. However, I object to what it means for those living around the Sydney West airport at Badgerys Creek. It means to my constituents that they will have a greater chance of having their sleep interrupted by various aircraft which will fly to Sydney West airport when it is opened because the curfew policy has been offered only to Kingsford Smith.

As an individual who has lived all of her life in Sydney's west and as a representative of the people in my community since 1971 in all three levels of government, I think I have a pretty good idea of how my constituents will react to this bill, with all its inherent meaning, once it is passed. While my electorate is a fair distance away from electorates in the inner city of Sydney and the North Shore, the seats where the speakers on any issue concerning Sydney airport are usually based, given the impending development of Sydney West airport I think it fair to say that in the year 2000 this bill could have an even greater effect on Sydney's west and its population than on any other area.

The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill is about Sydney West airport as much as it is about Kingsford Smith. Unfortunately, as much as I would like to be standing here today talking about how the bill treats the residents of both areas with equal consideration and respect, I am afraid that I cannot. I think it behoves me to inform the House, and the rest of Australia for that matter, that Sydney's centre is no longer a five-kilometre radius around the GPO, which is the popular misconception. Its centre is now Parramatta or perhaps even further west. That is where it is geographically and population wise. If we keep expanding at the present rate, in the next 20 years Sydney airport will be sitting on the peripheries of the greater city area.

There is a real danger in the debate over Sydney's needs for a second airport and the problems at Kingsford Smith of marginalising the people of Sydney's greater western area, where Sydney's centre really lies. Why is it that the desire of the people whom I represent from Sydney's west for a peaceful night's sleep free from air traffic noise is not seen as important as that of those residents living around Kingsford Smith? Far be it from me to appear cynical, but has someone recently carried out a study and ascertained that anybody living west of Parramatta needs less sleep than people living around Kingsford Smith? If this is the case, I would like to be informed of it, because I certainly have not read of it.
I appreciate the bill before the House. In particular, I appreciate the following comment of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The people of western Sydney can be reassured that the government's comprehensive updating of the environmental impact statement for the new airport will have as its central objective the prevention of noise nuisance arising from night-time operations. It is fundamentally important that we learn the lessons of Sydney airport and ensure that future generations of western suburbs residents are not exposed to excessive noise.

It is a little different from what the Howard coalition would have us believe. Quite frankly, in all of the debate that has occurred about Sydney's west the opposition has seemed to say, `Let's just ship it out west, pour a few sprinkles on it, stick a cherry on top and then they can learn to live with it.' I believe we are now telling the opposition that this is where we stand and fight for the respect and the consideration that we deserve. Whether we win or lose, fight we will.

PARA.TAB: As I said before in this House when debating Sydney West airport, my community is not ungrateful for the jobs and the improved infrastructure that development of Badgerys Creek will bring. Apart from the odd stirrer, I do not think anyone is under the misapprehension that Sydney does not need a second airport. We are willing to share the burden with the residents of the inner city. What we are saying is that we do not want to bear an uneven burden when Sydney West airport opens. I do not see why we have to, especially when upon the passing of this bill and the opening of Badgerys Creek the residents of Sydney's inner city will benefit. Why can't we all benefit from the passing of the bill? `We don't want it, so you can have it.' The coalition cannot tell us that in the west, but that is how the people of my community will read the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill. And why not? There should not be any surprise in their reaction when it basically spells this out in the bill.

Clause 17 states that once Sydney West airport is operational, once it is capable of handling night-time freight aircraft movements, approval for such movements at Sydney airport will be withdrawn. Sydney West will get them all. This bill is saying, `When Sydney West can take the pressure off Kingsford Smith, we're going to have to give it to them.' This is despite reports in the press this weekend that Badgerys Creek, operating on a curfew, will not make any difference to the noise problems that residents around Kingsford Smith presently experience. If that is the case, shouldn't any noise emanating from Sydney's airports be shared equally? In my book, sharing something evenly means both sides are balanced. If one airport has a curfew to balance the noise demands on its nearby residents, surely the other airport could have one as well.

The basic part of this bill and that which I want to object to most strongly—and let me spell it out so that there is no misunderstanding for the record—is that it seems to me the sins of the father are about to be vested upon the son. Let it also be said that I stand here today not because of the considerable strength of opinion on this matter in my electorate but because of the strong personal feelings that I have always had on this issue. Night operations of aircraft at Sydney airport—an airport that supposedly already has a curfew in place—and the amount of traffic that comes into the airport outside these curfew hours have seen one of the largest and most vocal protests ever organised in Sydney, perhaps in Australia, develop over these last few years. The only other protest that I can remember ever reaching a similar scale in recent times was the Gordon below Franklin fiasco in the early 1980s. I am not convinced that, by strengthening this curfew and by having a non-curfew operation at Sydney West airport—when it opens—there will not be a similar ground swell of public opinion.

Remember that the outcry you have at Sydney airport at the moment is over an airport that supposedly already has a curfew in place. Can you imagine the tumult that will reign in Sydney's west once a no-curfew airport begins at Badgerys Creek—given, as I have already pointed out, that Sydney's west is now the heart of the city?

One of the main thrusts concerning the development of Sydney West airport has been that the environmental problems presently being experienced at Kingsford Smith will not be repeated. The Minister for Transport has given me that guarantee, and he repeated it again in a speech in this House on 10 May when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are similarly determined to ensure that the environmental problems of Sydney's existing airport are not visited upon those living near the new airport. We are doing so because for too long Sydney's aviation infrastructure has suffered from short-term planning and a lack of integration. That approach has resulted in major capacity problems and an enormous burden upon the residents of Sydney's inner city.

I agree wholeheartedly with the minister, and I sympathise 100 per cent with the residents of those suburbs surrounding Kingsford Smith. The problems they have there now need to be solved, not moved. They need to be dealt with, not delivered elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: While I am convinced this bill will help solve those problems for the inner city, I hope it will not mean the beginning of problems for Sydney's west. Sydney West airport needs to be developed so that the present problems of Kingsford Smith do not spring up there as well. We are all agreed on that, surely. So how does making Badgerys Creek a no-curfew operation solve the problem? It does not; it simply moves it. I want to make it perfectly clear that I am happy to see the curfew at Kingsford Smith tightened. I am simply requesting that the same courtesy being extended to constituents in Sydney's inner city be extended to those in my electorate and in electorates surrounding Badgerys Creek.

It has been pointed out to me that Sydney West airport will always be a no-curfew operation, that this is already enshrined in regulation. True—but I will always oppose it. The arguments for the no-curfew policy for Badgerys Creek are well structured and convincing. However, in years to come I feel that these explanations will ring hollow in my constituents' ears, just as they are doing now among people in the inner city.

Despite my personal disappointment over the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill's no-curfew ramifications for Sydney West airport, I am determined not to let it, or this speech, be used to feed the rumour machine that is working at an increasingly feverish pace in my community and in surrounding areas. The people behind these rumour mills purport to act in the community's interest, but in reality are either only acting for their own self-gain or as fronts for the coalition, spoiling for the sake of spoiling, dragging down the government's concerted attempts at improving community consultation over issues such as flight paths at Badgerys Creek, solely for their own political point scoring, and I will continue to expose their pathetic actions at every opportunity I have.

You see, although I may take an independent stance on the curfew issue at Sydney West airport, I am still convinced that the only people capable of delivering a new airport in Sydney's west by the year 2000, built with the interests of my community at heart, is the present federal Labor government. The Sydney Airport Curfew Bill is indicative of this fact. Its coverage is exhaustive. Its scope is wide ranging. The findings of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which is chaired by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), show the private member's bill of the Leader of the Opposition to be what it always was—as much hot air as you could get from the back of a jet aeroplane.

Outside of the inner city, the people in Sydney's west can see only the real coalition behind that caring, sharing front. They know that Sydney West airport is necessary for their own future, as well as for that of Sydney, but they also know that if it is to be built with the help of a coalition government—Lord help us—they will not know what will hit them once the first aircraft start rolling in. I have received from the Minster for Transport very public assurances that the Sydney West airport will only go ahead after the most careful community consultation process that can be put into operation has been carried out, and I am pleased to say that the wheels are already in motion in this regard.

In relation to airport policy, the coalition are the greatest hypocrites. Since the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill is obviously aimed primarily at that opposition, let me draw to the House's attention some of the machinations which the opposition have been guilty of during the building of the third runway at Kingsford Smith. While shadow minister for tourism and aviation, the member for Fadden (Mr Jull), back in 1991, demanded the federal government stop procrastinating with the third runway at Kingsford Smith. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: This government has turned procrastination into an artform.

The honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), the Leader of the National Party of Australia, also managed to raise his voice over the third runway. He claimed that to delay the runway's development meant threatening the lives of those using the crowded airport.

PARA.TAB: After the third runway's completion last year, after its consistently successful operation, and after praise by the airline industry, the opposition leader is now calling for the reintroduction of the east-west runway for the sake of a few votes in his and his colleagues' electorates on the leafy North Shore. He wants to close the third runway and open the east-west corridor, against advice from the airline industry and, most importantly, against the interests of safety.

I cannot believe how the opposition can front up in this House, time and time again, and also front up to the Australian people in fact, and make these claims about Sydney airport's future when they have no credibility. They change their position when it suits them, and they generally try to wreak havoc for the sake of petty political point scoring—not because they want to see Sydney develop a cohesive and well-thought-out airport operation, but solely because they want to discredit the government. I condemn them. I condemn them for their pettiness, vindictiveness and spitefulness, and the people of Sydney do as well.

With regard to the construction of Sydney West airport, the opposition love to sit in judgment, heckling from the sidelines, but they do not actually talk over that heckling about the real reason behind what they say is the government's continued delay or procrastination—in their words again—in the building of Badgerys Creek. I will tell them what it is. It is because this government is committed, more so than ever before, to involving the community in its decision making process. We know the hard decisions regarding Sydney's future have to be made. We know that these decisions are never going to be easy and that they are not going to be delivered to the liking of every interest group, but we will continue to work to make sure that this time we get it right.

I must put on record, too, my congratulations to the minister and to the authority for opening, just recently, an information house on Badgerys Creek Road near Badgerys Creek airport. It certainly has been welcomed by communities around the area, and certainly by constituents living in my electorate.

Another point that continually needs to be raised when we talk about the construction of airports—and I think it was raised previously in this debate by the member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott)—is the infrastructure that will be sorely needed when we have this airport at Badgerys Creek up and running by the year 2000. Road patterns have been designated; in fact this government has contributed to the orbital link which will connect the M4 to the M5, and I commend them for it.

The other area which is of grave concern to people living in the west is the lack of a railway line structure. Designated areas have been looked at but, at this stage, an environmental impact statement has not been undertaken. A basic need of any airport is to have rail infrastructure in place well before the freight planes—or, for that matter, the passenger planes—start coming in.

If we are really to look at Sydney's Kingsford Smith and Sydney West airports as running in conjunction with one another—and I have always said they are not to supplement one another but are to run in conjunction with one another—the infrastructure must be there not only to transport the goods that are needed and provided but also so that people will have the opportunity of coming in to either airport. I believe that infrastructure must be in place well before the year 2000, and certainly well before the airport is built and completed.

I also believe that the state government of New South Wales must acknowledge that the responsibility of rail within the state of New South Wales rests within their area of responsibility, and that it is up to them to come to the party—not with just rhetoric and words—in negotiation with the federal government regarding where that rail line is to be built and who will fund the cost of building that rail line. We do not need just a rail line: we need a good airport, and we need it well constructed.

As I indicated earlier today in my speech to the House, we need community consultation on flight paths. Many of the rumours circulating in the area include the statement that we know the flight paths and that we are just not telling people. We know that is not correct. I know that everyone in government and in opposition know that is not correct, but we have to continue, with the cooperation of the minister and the transport department, to make sure that the consultations with respect to airport strategies, airport policies and flight paths are taken in conjunction with people, and that people's concerns are kept in mind.

Being parochial and representing an electorate like the one I do, I would say that I see nothing wrong with the flight paths going south-west. Other people might object to that. People who are looking at simulating aircraft flight paths in the vicinity of Sydney and Badgerys Creek may say that I do not have the information and that, therefore, I do not know what I am talking about. I probably do not.

I can only stand in this House without the expertise of my professionals and offer them the advice of my constituents. They are saying that they live in this area and they have built in the area. They have come to this area to appreciate it, and they like what they have. They were never informed in the early 1960s, 1970s or 1980s that there was going to be an airport at west Sydney. This decision was not made until 1985. They are now telling us to make sure that we listen to them and that when that construction goes ahead it is done with the full cooperation, consultation and involvement of the people in those communities who are going to be affected by it.

I commend the present bill to the House. I feel sure that the guarantees the minister has delivered in this bill to Kingsford Smith and the surrounding areas in tightening the curfew will also be the same guarantees that we in the west will welcome when we start looking at the consultation process involving the flight paths. I can then truly go back to my constituents and say that at least we are taking on board what they are saying to us.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look back at the history of the way in which the Australian Labor Party itself ruthlessly exploited airport issues over a long period of time and the sense in which I think they are now hoist on their own petard. The fact is that, for as long as I can remember—having joined the parliament in 1973—airports have been an issue in Sydney.

The former Liberal governments were seeking resolutions for those who wanted second airports planned for Sydney in that time. A number of studies were undertaken to identify suitable sites in places like Somersby, north of Sydney, and Richmond, west of Sydney. When we reached the point at which the government, having proceeded to develop the extra runway at Kingsford Smith, decided to close down the east-west operations in order to enhance its support in those seats in Sydney which it always saw as critical to it, there were a new batch of losers. TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—Yes, the seats of Sydney and Grayndler. But, of course, the seats occupied by opposition members did not really matter—seats such as Bennelong, Bradfield, Mackellar, Berowra and Mitchell, as well as the electorate of Cook to the south held by my colleague Mr Dobie.

PARA.TAB: What we see here is a management issue by the government wanting to convince those people who are as angry as the minister and the member for Grayndler outlined that it can manage the issue. They are worried about the level of support that the No Aircraft Noise Party might have and they are concerned that Independents might well be able to take ministers out of their formerly safe seats. Because the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) brought forward a bill to legislate permanently for a Sydney airport curfew, the government again wanted to try to manage the issue by introducing this bill to codify the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Curfew) Regulations. SPEECH.PARA: This Bill imposes a curfew at Sydney Airport, together with a number of related restrictions.

The Bill reflects the present curfew controls embodied in the Air Navigation (Aerodrome Curfew) Regulations together with some additional controls following the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure advisory report . . .

In other words, we are dealing with a bill that was designed simply to put legislation into the government's name to give effect to the private member's bill moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition. PARA.TAB: "PART 3A—OTHER NOISE ABATEMENT MEASURES

SPEECH.PARA: 20A As soon as possible after the commencement of this Act, the Minister must give a direction under section 16 of the Air Services Act 1995 to require Airservices Australia to revise the noise abatement procedures for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport to disperse more equitably the noise generated by the operation and use of aircraft landing at, or taking off from, the aerodrome by increasing the use of the runway known as the east-west runway.".

PARA.TAB: I want to associate myself with that amendment and the arguments adduced by my colleague the Leader of the Opposition, because the impact, particularly to the north-west of Sydney, has been as significant in my electorate as it has been to so many of my colleagues. A delegation of six Federal Labor MPs, including three Ministers, will also meet with Mr Brereton next Monday in a bid to convince him of the need to take immediate action on the runway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Sydney Airport Curfew Bill which is currently before the House. Unlike the private member's bill proposed by the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), which would have merely entrenched the existing curfew arrangements established by regulations, this bill will tighten the curfew in a number of important respects. When it comes into effect those suffering from aircraft noise should experience some significant improvement in their circumstances.

PARA.TAB: The bill addresses a number of key points that I and others have been particularly concerned about for some time. To take one example, as a resident of Leichhardt I am well aware of the particular aggravation caused by the final bunch of aircraft taking off immediately before the curfew comes into effect at 11 p.m. The problem is compounded by the fact that these movements typically consist of heavy international jet aircraft leaving on long journeys with a full load of fuel. I can assure members that having one's sleep disturbed by a jumbo jet rumbling overhead at full power is not a pleasant experience.

The measures in this bill should help to ameliorate this problem. Likewise, I am sure that the tightening of the weekend curfew will be welcomed by my constituents, as will the significantly increased penalty provisions and the further restrictions on freight movements during the curfew hours.

This bill is given added importance by the impending sale of airport leases, which has led to a degree of public anxiety as to the sort of operational regime that will apply in future. It will be important to dispel this impression—and in this context I note that the forthcoming leasing bills will contain much improved democratic controls over airport planning, development and operations. In particular, many people undoubtedly fear a progressive weakening of the curfew provisions.

This bill clearly moves in the opposite direction—towards a progressive tightening. I intend to work to ensure that things continue to move in this direction. This bill is a useful start, but much more will need to be done in future. Relief for seven hours out of 24 is hardly adequate. Not everyone is a night owl choosing to go to bed at 11 p.m., or an early riser bounding out of bed at 6 a.m.—not to mention the needs of young children.

The early completion of the Sydney West airport is crucial in this regard, as indicated by the specific provisions in the bill requiring the relocation of freight movements during the curfew hours once the new airport is completed. There is no doubt that further significant improvements in the curfew at Kingsford Smith will depend on the availability of the new airport at Badgerys Creek.

Ever since the final go-ahead was given to the third runway in 1991—a decision which, as the public record shows, I and others strongly opposed—I have worked assiduously to keep the second airport alive. Following the government's decision to build the third runway, the initial intention was to build no more than a small general aviation facility at Badgerys Creek. This has since been progressively upgraded. In 1991 I successfully lobbied the then minister, Bob Collins, to have the airport upgraded to being jet capable, and this proposal was subsequently endorsed by cabinet.

The infrastructure elements of last year's Working Nation statement and this year's budget provided me, as a minister on the Expenditure Review Committee, an opportunity to support further enhancements. The proposal, as members would know, has been further significantly upgraded to provide some $760 million to build an airport and associated infrastructure, with a 2.9-kilometre runway capable of handling all but the largest jets operating near the extremity of their range.

But there is no doubt that more has to be done. I strongly believe—and I am speaking here as a local member rather than as a minister—that the proposed runway should be built to its intended ultimate length of four kilometres as soon as possible and that if the airlines persist with their current reluctance to move to Sydney West we should be prepared to put in place a pricing and regulatory regime designed to ensure that the new airport picks up a significant share of the traffic rather than just a small proportion of the projected growth at Kingsford Smith.

The bill before the House begins this process by tightening the curfew further once Sydney West airport is available, but further measures are likely to be required, in my view. These should include a capacity cap at Kingsford Smith airport, a program of transferring categories of aircraft such as freight and charter, an increasing proportion of international traffic and the necessary development of Sydney West airport to handle the demand so generated.

I reject the argument put forward by some that the question of the site for Sydney's second airport be reopened. Badgerys Creek was selected after an exhaustive process that examined every conceivable site within a reasonable radius of Sydney. This included an explicit examination of issues like fog and turbulence, which have been referred to in evidence to the Senate committee. The Badgerys Creek EIS contains a useful summary table covering these matters for each of the possible airport sites.

The last thing we need to do at this stage, in my view, is to reopen the second airport site issue. To do so will guarantee that there will be no possibility of a second airport until well into the next century. I fully understand the concerns of my colleagues representing seats in western Sydney that the EIS process be properly updated and that their constituents be provided with genuinely useful information. This is obviously imperative. But I would say to them that there is absolutely no comparison between the kind of noise impact being experienced by people in inner Sydney and that likely to occur as a result of operations at Sydney West airport.

I will turn to the member for Bennelong's proposed amendment on the east-west runway in a moment. Many people, understandably, are anxious to seize on this as a short-term panacea. I will argue that, rather than being a panacea, such a decision raises the risk of a significant worsening of the problem in the medium term. But first I have to make a few comments on the breathtaking hypocrisy of the member for Bennelong on these issues. At the time when all other representatives of electorates significantly affected by the airport were opposing the third runway, and when the government was locked in intense and closely divided debate on the issue, all members of the opposition, including the member for Bennelong, were raising a constant clamour of demands for the government to stop dithering and build the thing immediately. The member for Bennelong's contribution right at the crucial time of the cabinet debate back on 21 March 1989 was to say to Mike Carlton on 2GB:

SPEECH.PARA: I grew up under the flight paths in the St George area of Sydney and know something about the politics of the area and I've always regarded the issue as being grossly exaggerated in terms of the impact on the local residents.

He now professes shock and surprise about the impact that this is having on people living to the north of the airport. However, the whole point of the third runway was to raise Sydney's airport capacity by replacing a configuration of two intersecting runways with one in which the great bulk of movements are handled on two parallel runways, capable of operating independently once all the relevant systems are in place.

PARA.TAB: That this would mean a major increase in the noise burden for those to the north was transparently obvious to all, apparently bar the member for Bennelong. The proposal to reduce the east-west runway to a residual cross-wind runway was clearly spelt out in the government announcement of March 1989, and the subsequent EIS proceeded on this premise. This is precisely why I and all other Labor and Independent members representing seats near the airport—including, I might add, those who actually stood to benefit from reduced movements on the east-west runway—strongly opposed the proposition from the outset, and made detailed submissions to this effect throughout the EIS process. All this apparently escaped the attention of the member for Bennelong until very recently.

Before coming in I had a look at the second volume of the supplement to the third runway EIS, which contains an alphabetical tabulation of the consultant's responses to submissions responding to the draft EIS. In response to my own submission, for example, some 60 distinct points are listed and addressed. There is no record of any submission from the member for Bennelong—between Hotel, Intercontinental and Howell, M. there is a vacuum. Certain of the information in the EIS has, of course, been shown to be wrong—particularly the gross underestimation of the rate of traffic growth and the meteorological information that underpinned estimates of the number of northerly take-offs. But the basic operational principles relating to runway usage, and the appalling implications of these for people to the north, have been explicit and clear at least since 1989.
Where was the member for Bennelong when this highly contentious public controversy was going on? Was he asleep at the time? Or perhaps he just wanted the third runway to be built but not used.

On the last point, Mr Speaker, I return to the 1989 Mike Carlton interview which I referred to earlier. When the proposition was put to the member for Bennelong that some people may have a reduction in noise once the third runway was built, he replied:

SPEECH.PARA: Many people will because you'll have the north-south pattern. I think the case for it on general interest grounds is absolutely overwhelming.
Note he said, `because you'll have the north-south pattern'. In other words, he was then extolling as a virtue the very shift to north-south operations which he now professes to abhor.

PARA.TAB: If I could return to the east-west issue, I strongly recommend that honourable members, if they get a chance, take a close look at the submissions and verbal evidence given to the Senate committee now looking at aircraft noise.

TAB.TAB: Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read just about all of it thus far and it sheds some interesting light on these issues. The claim has been made that the decision on the east-west runway was motivated by solely political considerations. There have been submissions arguing different viewpoints presented by Airservices Australia, which is the successor organisation to the CAA, the pilots, the air traffic controllers and others, and I see that the airlines themselves have now bought into the debate.

PARA.TAB: However, the statutory responsibility for the safety of operational procedures at Sydney airport lies with Airservices Australia, whose staff are directly responsible for air traffic control. They presented a detailed submission to the Senate committee, which included 11 possible scenarios for runway use at Kingsford Smith airport, encompassing Airservices Australia's preferred options, as well as various alternative proposals that have been canvassed in public debate. Of these, six were regarded as viable options from Airservices Australia's point of view and only one of these involved the regular use of the east-west runway—that is, using it as other than a cross-wind runway.

This proposal was to allow five to 10 small turbo prop aircraft per hour to take off on that part of the east-west runway that lies to the east of the intersection with the north-south runway. This is an option heavily favoured by regional users. Airservices Australia argued that every aircraft thus moved out of the main north-south stream would free up one to two slots for heavy jet movements on the north-south axis, since the smaller, slower aircraft require more separation than the jets.

The obvious downside to this for people to the north is the scope it creates for yet more heavy jet movements and noise as traffic demand continues to grow. Furthermore, by enhancing total capacity at KSA, it reduces pressure for the early development of the second airport. I regard this as the worst case scenario for the future of Sydney airport.

Airservices Australia also analysed options for the regular use of the east-west runway by large jet aircraft. In essence, two cases were considered, corresponding—to use the standard jargon—to `dependent' and `independent' operations. Dependent operations refers to a situation where movements on one runway are separated from, and slotted between, operations on the other runway. Independent operations—also called Simops—involve aircraft on one runway stopping short of the intersection with the other runway, thereby allowing operations on the other runway to proceed independently. Of these two options, only Simops would allow a comparable movement rate to parallel operations. However, Airservices Australia's position is emphatic, and I quote from their submission:

SPEECH.PARA: Airservices would not be prepared to restore simultaneous independent runway operations involving the use of the east west runway in intersecting operations with the parallel north-south runway system.

Airservices Australia cite safety factors in support of this position and on this they have been absolutely consistent. They did not like Simops with a single north-south runway. They like them even less with two north-south runways. And, contrary to what was said earlier in this debate by the Leader of the Opposition, this view is broadly supported by the air traffic controllers. At the Senate committee, the President of the Civil Air Operations Officers Association, Mr Robert Lorschy, was asked about the safety of cross-runway operations. He replied:
They are less safe. They rely more heavily upon the skill of the aerodrome controller in judging the point of conflict between two aircraft operating on the crossing runway set up . . .

Now it could be that our air traffic controllers are overly conservative in these matters. I know that some pilots hold to this view. I have just returned from the United States and observed some things there that I suspect would have made our controllers' hair stand on end. But my point is that, in judging the likely impact of a decision to reopen the east-west runway, we cannot ignore the stance of the organisation and people with day-to-day operational control of the airport and responsibility for its safety.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that part of the story here is an understandable difference of perspective between those responsible for control and safety of individual aircraft, the pilots, and those whose responsibility it is for the safety and efficient functioning of an airport system.

On some issues, undoubtedly, the pilot's viewpoint has to be treated very seriously. I instance the issue of acceptable cross-wind tolerances where I know a number of pilots have some serious concerns about operations at Sydney. I believe these concerns have to be taken very seriously, and I have raised this matter with the minister.

As I mentioned earlier, the other possibility is dependent operations, in which an aircraft is not cleared to move until the aircraft on the other runway has passed through the intersection point. However, Airservices Australia claim that this mode of operation would result in a substantial reduction in the hourly movement rate well below current demand levels.

I mention these points to show that the simple panacea of restoring east-west operations is far from straightforward. The underlying problem is that demand for aircraft movements has continued to grow far more rapidly than projected a few years ago, to the point that the extra capacity provided by the third runway will soon be exhausted. In these circumstances, a simple return to the old status quo is untenable. Things have moved beyond that.

It seems to me that the advocates of the east-west runway reopening need to think carefully about what is likely, in practice, to happen if they were to wake up one day and find that the east-west runway had been reopened for more than cross-wind operations. Is any government of either persuasion going to instruct Airservices Australia to restore Simops with two parallel runways in the face of emphatic warnings that it is unsafe? Such a government would be publicly torn to shreds the next time there was an incident—as has happened regularly in the past—or worse. Or is it realistic to imagine any real world government reverting to dependent operations on intersecting runways which would be likely to produce a major capacity bottleneck affecting the air transportation system of the whole country?

I think far the most likely outcome, if not immediately then in the not too distant future, would be the worst case scenario I described earlier of the east-west being used mainly for intersection take-offs, enabling more heavy jet capacity on the north-south axis and a significant worsening of conditions for my constituents. I emphasise: this would mean an extra 10 to 20 heavy jet movements per hour, potentially, for those underneath the existing north-south runway—hardly a panacea. This point is now well understood by the more astute community activists. Just today the newly elected Mayor of Hunters Hill, Jane Waddell of the No Aircraft Noise Party, made exactly the same points as I have just made in an interview with the ABC's PM program. Ms Waddell said:

SPEECH.PARA: I support any attempts to share the burden a little. But I think the east west runway is a double-edged sword. Because if you open the east west runway and take out all the small aircraft and put those down on the east west runway and then fill all the slots up here with lots of other planes, and then keep winding the capacity of the airport up, which is what's going to happen, our situation here will be that for a very short time we will have relief, and then the whole thing will start over again.

It is not just government ministers and members making this point. It is also significant, I think, that the coalition's transport spokesman, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), invoked the position of the regional airlines during the debate earlier today. What they have explicitly advocated is the very worst case scenario I have just described, together with a few other little nasties like allowing take-offs to the north from the third runway.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, it is my firm belief that the Sydney airport noise problem is easily the most important urban environmental issue in the country today. The bill we are debating might be said to be an incremental measure, but it is a very worthwhile one that will bring quite tangible benefits, and not a little reassurance to those affected. It is important that we seek genuine solutions through the early development of Sydney West airport and measures to ensure that it starts to take the burden off Kingsford Smith as soon as possible.
