DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In her reply to a question without notice from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) last week, remarks by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) contained the outrageous claim that the Council for Civil Liberties in Western Australia was `in name only' and that `one of the travesties of Western Australian public life is that the Council for Civil Liberties is controlled by a group of very conservative people' who were secretive, hid the council's constitution and failed to publicise their meetings.

PARA.TAB: The minister knows full well that the council is an incorporated body the constitution of which is a public document, and invites the public and all members of the Western Australian parliament to its annual general meeting as well as providing a service to the public 24 hours a day.

The minister's reply was, of course, thoroughly in keeping with her totally disingenuous smokescreen of prevarications and irrelevancies in these matters. The minister wants us to accept that, to quote her own words:

SPEECH.PARA: I would have taken little notice of any correspondence with the Council for Civil Liberties on matters affecting divorce law reform serious enough to raise them with both the Western Australian and Commonwealth Attorneys General.

What is even more astonishing is that she was, nevertheless, prepared to discuss with Mr Peter Weygers, himself a practising psychologist, her views on the psychology of Penny Easton's suicide in a letter dated 16 December 1992, not long after her death.

PARA.TAB: The minister's attack, by name, on Mr Peter Weygers, four times elected mayor of the town of Claremont, and a person who only a few days ago was nominated by the West Australian newspaper as one of `Western Australia's most admired citizens', is typical of her stance throughout this sorry affair.

But what is ironic is that in denying any remembrance of a protracted correspondence with Mr Weygers, as president of the council, and of having knowledge of this Commonwealth parliament's divorce laws, the minister seems also to have forgotten that, as a divorced person herself, she must have had first-hand experience of divorce court procedure.

Even more ironic, in view of her claim that she knew nothing of the law, is that her co-conspirator, Mr John Halden MLC, in what has become known as the Easton affair was immediately prior to his election to the parliament of Western Australia, and for six years, employed as an officer of the Family Court in Western Australia. He must have known he was using the privilege of parliament to break the law, by using false information about the Family Court proceedings to which Penny Easton could not reply.

I have in my possession copies of the letters which clearly demonstrate that the Minister for Human Services and Health had indeed been fully informed about the Council for Civil Liberties' campaign, against the secrecy provisions of section 121 of this Commonwealth parliament's Family Law Act of 1975.

I am ashamed that a fellow Western Australian should have made such a defamatory attack upon the Council for Civil Liberties and its public-spirited officers. Mr Speaker, I would like to assure you and the House that, contrary to what the minister said, the council's work and its support for the liberty of the individual is highly valued by all those in Western Australia with any respect for decency and honesty.

I find it almost impossible to believe, therefore, that the minister, a divorcee and a member of the very party which prides itself on having created a no-fault divorce procedure, and especially one that barred publicity, should now claim that she was unaware of the Family Law Act's secrecy provisions. It is beyond comprehension.

Perhaps I should end by paraphrasing Winston Churchill's famous remark about secrecy: `The greater the truth, the bigger the bodyguard of lies and deception needed to conceal it.' Here I think we have the answer to what lies at the heart of the Easton affair and the Minister for Human Services and Health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight in the adjournment debate I want to pay tribute to the Australian volunteer coastguard movement. On the weekend of 12 to 13 August, the national AGM of the Australian Volunteer Coastguard Association was held in Cairns. I would like to thank the association for the hospitality extended to me by National Commodore Clark and his colleagues at the squadron dinner which was held on the Saturday night.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Volunteer Coastguard Association was first formed in 1961 in Victoria due to a defined need, moulded on the US Coastguard Auxiliary and adapted to suit the Australian scene. Since then, it has spread to all states except Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Some 90 per cent of Australia's population of 17.5 million live within 120 kilometres of the coast and over 70 per cent live in a coastal belt running from my electorate in Far North Queensland to Adelaide in South Australia, which is where the Australian Volunteer Coastguard Association is established.

They are the largest single volunteer marine rescue and marine education organisation in Australia and indeed the Southern Hemisphere. Their total membership, including associate members, stands at approximately 11,700, with 2,514 being regular professional volunteers. There are 89 association owned rescue boats and 147 radio bases under the control of 63 flotillas, and expansion is continuing in areas of need.

The coastguard association is a registered charity and a volunteer non-profit organisation. All members are dedicated professional volunteers who freely give up their spare time and vessels to provide the service. No member gets paid for what they do and funding is provided through the generosity of the public and private enterprise and in some states through state funding. A supplementary role is served in some areas by the water police. It has to be said that they regularly risk their lives to save others.

It is worth going through the objectives of the association, which are to promote safety in boating and the use of pleasure craft in the Commonwealth of Australia; to assist in the preservation of life and property of the members of the association and others; to assist persons on or adjacent to the waters of the Commonwealth of Australia who, as a result of misadventure or otherwise, have endangered their lives or the lives of others or who must conveniently be assisted by members of the association; to train members and the public in the use of seacraft and seamanship, first aid and resuscitation; and to train personnel capable of assisting in the defence of the Commonwealth of Australia upon the seas and elsewhere. In the latter, the association works in close cooperation with state and federal authorities, including Coastwatch and customs.

I congratulate in particular the work of the Cairns coastguard flotilla and also the flotillas in Port Douglas and Thursday Island which are part of my electorate. The Cairns flotilla is now proudly led by Commodore Lucille Jackley and Vice-Commodore Lorelle Wilton. On the night of 12 August, life membership was awarded to Vice-Commodore Barry Crittenden of Cairns, to Frank Carter from Mourilyan, who was previously from Cairns, and posthumously to Bill McPherson of Sydney. The award of substantive rank was awarded to Max Griffin of the Port Douglas flotilla. I congratulate them for their long-term service to the community. Again, I take this opportunity to congratulate the Australian Volunteer Coastguard Association for the voluntary work that they do very well in protecting and saving lives on the Australian coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a subject that has been widely debated in the other place over recent weeks but which has been largely ignored in this place, other than by the member for Moore (Mr Filing), and that is China's program for nuclear tests. China should be of great concern to this parliament. Its human rights record has been appalling. At the moment it is managing to create a grotesque mixture of the worst aspects of state socialist dictatorship and unrestrained primitive capitalism. This is occurring against a background of political instability. China's economic development is strengthening regionalism and threatens Beijing's centralised dictatorship at a time when a succession crisis is building as the country's leaders await the death of Deng Xiaoping.

PARA.TAB: The Chinese military is steadily becoming more assertive. According to official Chinese figures, military spending has increased by 200 per cent over the past seven years. There have been reports that some generals have called for Deng's designated successor, the State President and General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, Jiang Zemin, to stand down. China has displayed increasingly belligerent behaviour over the disputed Spratly Islands.

We have just seen a particularly provocative series of missile tests off the coast of Taiwan. Its current series of nuclear tests appears to be part of this trend. Over the last few months much has been made of the fact that France tests its nuclear weapons in a colony, not on its own soil. It could be argued that China does much the same.

China's nuclear tests are carried out at Lop Nor in the province Xinjiang in the far west of the country. Xinjiang lies in the heart of central Asia. It borders Tibet in the south; Mongolia in the east; Kirgizistan in the north; and Pakistan, Afghanistan and India in the west. Xinjiang literally means `new territories' and the province has a distinct history of its own. Like much of central Asia, it is a heavily Muslim populated area. For much of this century it looked more towards the Soviet Union than China, and an independent East Turkistan Republic briefly existed in the 1940s and still serves as an inspiration for nationalists.

It was not until the 1950s that firm attempts were made by Beijing to irreversibly integrate the region into the state, and the province was heavily colonised by Han Chinese. Efforts to collectivise agriculture have devastated the livelihoods of nomadic herders, traders and small scale farmers. The cultural revolution saw the destruction of many mosques, the burning of scriptures, persecutions of religious leaders and the suppression of any expression of nationalism and national customs seen as being separatist.

There is an enormous discrepancy between the economic and educational wellbeing of people in Xinjiang and those living in China proper. Xinjiang has been used as a dumping ground for thousands of China's prison population and restrictive family planning policies are enforced, despite earlier promises from Beijing not to apply them to the region.

There is concern that Xinjiang's soil composition makes it an entirely unsuitable site for nuclear weapons testing. China's test program has had predictable health effects on the local population. It has also damaged the agricultural industries that boomed in the area and has devastated local water supplies. Despite this, the tests continue and, to further exacerbate the problem, the region is used as a dumping ground for nuclear waste. It should be no surprise that many disturbances have occurred in the area over the last 15 years with demonstrations, riots and full scale fighting claiming several hundred lives.

China acceded to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty in 1992—less than a year after American intelligence had made the disturbing claim that it had been assisting Iran with the development of nuclear weapons, a claim repeated in the British press only last weekend. It has been claimed that China's test program is, in part, a protest against its lack of say when the treaty was originally formulated. China is keen to assert its power, not just in the region but on the world stage.

China cannot be ignored, as its nuclear program has shown, but it seems as if it is trying to elbow its way into a larger place at the world table. China must learn to adhere to the international norms other countries follow, and then China's rise may be a source of opportunity for other countries, not a source of danger.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August last, the Health Insurance Commission closed the Medicare-Medibank office at Toukley in my electorate and moved it to Lake Haven Shopping Centre, some five kilometres away. That action has caused major disruptions and unnecessary inconvenience to many thousands of my constituents. The commission has overlooked the fact, I am quite sure, that Toukley is the major medical services centre of Wyong shire. It serves the people of Norah Head, Toukley, Noraville, Budgewoi, the areas north of there and the area of Gorokan in the adjoining electorate of Dobell.

PARA.TAB: There are more than 60 health professionals operating at Toukley. They include 30 full-time GPs, 10 visiting specialists, two specialist centres, two radiology centres, three sports medicine centres, four physiotherapists, a large pathology service—with one more to open soon—and an almost completed medical centre for 10 more specialists. Medicare's nearby location was convenient for those medical service centres. There is a choice of some seven pharmacists close at hand for people who have to use those services.

Despite objections from the Toukley chamber of commerce, the people of Toukley and adjoining areas, local health professionals, pharmacists, doctors, aged care professionals, petitions signed by over 2,200 people in the immediate area, representations to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), wide objections in the media and my own efforts on their behalf, the health commission went ahead with that decision to close down the service.

I think that the commission did not think through the decision. It was not aware of the importance of Toukley Medical Centre and the fact that it was the major medical service centre in the Wyong shire. I think that they were made an offer that they found too good to refuse, an offer by the proprietors of the Lake Haven Shopping Centre, who see themselves threatened by an even bigger shopping centre coming up some kilometres down the highway at Westfield Tuggerah, just south of Wyong.

The landlord of the Toukley premises, with a lease coming up for reconsideration, was not given the opportunity to make a matching offer. He was not given the opportunity to take part in any kind of negotiations or discussions. The commission has, by its action—ill-considered be it—disadvantaged some 13,000 people. Many of those people are on low incomes, many of them are sick, many of them are receiving some form of support and many of them with those disabilities find it difficult to use infrequent public transport to go from the area they are residing in down to Lake Haven Shopping Centre, go to Medicare, wait for the next bus service, come back and then go to the pharmacist or deal with the only pharmacist that is at the Lake Haven Shopping Centre.

The public transport system between those areas that I have mentioned and Lake Haven, but particularly between Toukley and Norah Head and Noraville, my constituents assure me is not convenient for them. It is quite inconvenient, time consuming, uncomfortable and frustrating. I would have thought that they are matters that the commission is concerned about. Obviously, in this case they have made a decision and nothing is going to move them, or we are going to move them before we finish. Before we finish we want a Medicare-Medibank service of some form re-established at Toukley to meet the needs of the people. Medibank is optional, but Medicare is a service funded by taxpayers for all Australians and the convenience of that service ought to be a major consideration in the siting of those offices.

The minister has made it very clear to me that she will continue to raise with the commission the arguments that I am putting to the chamber here tonight. It is obviously a decision made by people in Sydney who have not thought through, as I said earlier, what is involved. I realise that ministers in these areas do have an opportunity to give some indication, but it is not as easy as that. That is why we are pressing much harder.

We are continuing the campaign. I will continue to raise this with the minister and will continue to bring the attention of people to petitions and fresh petitions, which we bring back to this chamber. They are being organised by the Toukley Chamber of Commerce because we want to see the people who use Medicare and Medibank in the Toukley and adjoining areas get the service that they are properly entitled to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House the good work of some Australian public servants, particularly the staff of the National Gallery of Australia and staff from the Cambodia desk of AusAID. The good work that they have done is in helping to restore the National Museum of Cambodia. With government money—$1.24 million and some private contributions from firms such as Transfield, the ANZ bank, the Henry Walker Group, Pacific Dunlop, Carlton United, Telstra, CSR, John Holland, Kinhill Engineers and the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation—they have restored this magnificent building to some of its former grandeur.

PARA.TAB: It is good to see that the staff from AusAID realise the importance of national museums to a community. In their little pamphlet that they produced they said that the Australian people realise the importance of conserving the treasures of Cambodia for the children and future of the kingdom of Cambodia. It also said that, by assisting the royal government of Cambodia to repair the museum, Australia is also assisting Cambodia to rediscover its unique cultural heritage and present it to the rest of the world.

This begs the question: if these things are so important that AusAID and the Australian government would assist in repairing a museum of another country, how is it that we fail to build a National Museum of Australia when it was one of the government's key cultural promises in the 1993 election? The 1995-98 corporate plan of the National Museum of Australia talks about building a gallery of Aboriginal Australia and developing specific venues, including old Parliament House and the Customs House in Sydney. It talks about communication technology strategies, but it does not talk about a permanent home for the collections that display our history and the `unique cultural heritage and present it to the rest of the world'.

What we have here is another broken promise from this government. It is a broken plan. It ignores the work of several different councils. The council which has a maximum number of 12 members currently only has five I believe. There is no funding. There is no funding in the forward estimates for the National Museum of Australia and one can only begin to believe that it has no future at all. The government admits the importance of national museums when speaking about the National Museum of Cambodia and, indeed, spends money overseas.
